Though occasional passages may be descriptive of the habits of one rather than another of these species, there is no evidence of any of these having been recognied as distinct: such names as ἀλιάετος, μελαν- ἀετος and λαγωφόνος have a fmystical or symbolic rather than a de- scriptive or specific meaning. ἀετὸς ὁ καλ.γνήσιος. Αrist. H. A. ix. 32, 619 μέγιστος τῶν ἀετῶν ἀπάντων, μείζων τε τῆς φήνης, τῶν δʼ ἀετῶν καὶ ἡμιόλιος, χρῶμα ξανθός, φαίνεται δὲ ὀλιγάκις ὦσπερ ἡ καλουμένη κύμινδις: cf. Plut. Amat. iv. 9; vide s.v. poρφiός. This is usually taken, as is also the χρυσάετος οr ἀστερίας of Αel. H. Α. ii. 39, to mean the Golden Eagle, Ai.Chννsaeίas (L.); the former birds are however said by both authors to be very rare, whereas the Gοlden Eagle is tme commonest eagle in Greece (Heldreich). Αristotlsʼs statement as to its sie is modified by Pliny (Η. Ν. x. 31 media magnitudine). The passage is obscure and mythical, as shown by the allusions to κύμινδις and φήνη: Pliny's phrase solaagae i- cοντπφίασ αrζίi. is a literal but perhaps incorrect tanslation of γνήσιος. Many of the general references to ἀετός apply more or lss closely to Ag. Chrysaeίs, . f. Arist. H. A. i. 32, 619, its nesting habits; vi. 6, y63 τίκτει τρία cά, ἐπῳάζει περὶ τριάκοντα ἠμέρας : ix. 321 θ19 b τοὺς δασύποδας οὐκ εὐθὺς λαμβάνει, ἀλλʼ εἰς τὸ πεδίον ἐάσας προελθεῖν, this last statement being, however, very obscure: Ael. ii. 39, c. ἄc. On the other hand accounts of the capture of snakes and stories of the combat with the Dragon (Arist. H. A. ix. 1, 609 τροφὴν γὰρ ποιεῖται τοὺς ὅφεις ὀ ἀετός: Ael.xvii.37; Il.xii.200; Aesch.Choeph.245; Soph. De Aurel. iv), are based on the habits of Carraeίs rallcas, the Short- toed Eagle, which feeds on reptiles, and partly also of the Limmer- geier. In Imhoof-Blumer and Κeller's Thierbilder we have coins of Chalcis in Euboea showing an Eagle with the snake in its beak, and also (pl. v. 9) a similar coin of Cyrene in which ume birdʼs head is evidently a Limmergeierʼs. The Vultures were frequently confused under the name ἀετός, .f. Αesch. Ag. 138 στυγεῖ δὲ δεῖπνον αἰετῶν: as also in the story of Pro- metheus, e.g. 1es. Th. 523; Aesch. Pr. V. 1022; Pr. Sol. ap. Cic. Q. Τusc.ii. 10; Apoll. Εh. ii. 1254, 1263,iii.851; Lucian, Prom.20 (i.203); D. Deοr. i. 1 (i. 205), ἂc. ἂε.; and as in the story of the death of Αeschylus, Ael. vii. 16, Plin.x. 3, Valer. The Solar Myth is also oriental, and in the Εig-veda the sun is frequently compared to a Vulture or Eagle hovering in the air. Thε Εagle is exempt from thirst, Ael. 1. sometimes evidently a solar emblem, as is 2ηνὸς δρνις in Aesch. Suppl. 212. Its name χρυσάετος is in like manner probably a translation of the gοlden hawkf Egyptian Horus. In its combat with the Hare, the Swan, the Bull, the Dragon, and so forth, these latter are probably symbolic of their stellar name-sakes, and in such cases, the hostile Eagle is, in the main, a stellar and not a solar emblem. The following are the principal facts in connexion with the constellation Aquila which seem to bear on the mytholgy of the Eagle. It rose nearly together with the Dolphin, and shortly after, and as it were in pursuit of, the Swan and the Serpent of Οphiuchus : it set as the Lion rose, whose leading star Eegulus was also called βaσιλίσκος, the Hare and the Dog- star rising simultaneously; it set together with Aquarius, known also as Ganymede the cup-bearer, and it was close beside and rose together with the Arrow of Sagittarius. It is not far distant from the constel- 1ation Lyra, which last constellation is also known as the Vulture; it and the Eagle are known respectively to later writers (and to the Arabs) as Aquila or Vultur cadens and volans or γὺψ καθήμενος and πετόμενος, nesr-el-waki and nesr-el-t3r, whence our modern names Vega and Αltair applied to their two principal stars. (See for Arabic and other references, Ideler, Sternnaumen, pp. 67, 106, ἄC.; also Grotiusʼ Aratus, Νοtae ad Imaff. pp. 54, 60, ἄc., dc. Aquila rose together with the 1atter stars of the Scorpion, but Lyra or the Vulture, rising a little earlier, seems to have been the true paranatellon of that sign : accordingly it is probably not the true Eagle but the Vulure or Aquila cadens, which, substituted for the unlcky Scorpion, figures with the other three cardinal signs of Leo, Taurus, and Aquarius, in the familiar imagery of Ε2ek.i. 10,X. 14, and Rev. iv.7. A Aolar myth is discussed s.v.ἀλιάετος. The combat with the Hare is interesting from its representation on a famous decadrachm of Agrigentum, as well as for the equally mystical description in Aesch.Ag. 115 βοσκόμενοι λαγίναν. (The symbolism con- nected with the Hare seems to me to be peculiarly complicated and difficult, and all tentative hypotheses are more than commonly liable to be overthrown.) The Eagle with the Serpent or Dragon occurs not only in classical coinage (Chalcis, Agrigentum, Gortyna, Siphnos, ἄc.), but also on Persian and Egyptian sculptures. Hartung, Eelig. und Myth. d. Gr. iii. p. 3; Duntνer in uhnʼs Ztschr. xiv. p. 207; Ε. Οder in Rh. Mus. f Philol. (Ν. 3.) xliii. p. 540 et seq.; Κeller op. c. pp. 304-320; Pott in Laarus and Steintmal's eischrift,xiv.p.46, 1883; j. Ε. Harrison, . Hellen. Stdies, viii. 439λ45, 1887, M. οf Anc. Αthens, p. lxiv. The Νightingaleʼs song, as Coleridge discovered, is not melancholy. It was a spirit of religious mysticism that 'First named these notes a melancholy strain, And many a poet echoes the conceit.' I believe the innumerable references to the melancholy lay of ἀδονίς οr ἀηδών, and to the lament for τυς, to be for the most part veiled allusions to the worship of Adonis or Atys; that is to say, t the mysterious and melancholy ritual of the departing year, when women awept for Tammuz': Ἀδὼνιʼ ἄγομεν, καὶ τὸν Ἀδωνιν κλάομεν ‖ This conjecture is partially supported by the confusion between ἀηδονίς and ἀδωνηίς, by the mythical relations between the Νightingale and the Swallow, and by the known connexion of both with the rites of Adonis. Compare also Thuc. ii. 29 ὀ μέν ἐν Δαυλίᾳ τῆς Φωκίδος νῦν καλουμένης γῆς, ὀ Τηρεὺς ὀκει τότε ὑπὸ Θρᾳκῶν οἰκουμένηςʼ καὶ τὸ ἔργον τὸ ππερὶ τὸν Ττυν αἱ γυναῖκες ἐν τῇ γῇ ταύτῃ ἔπραξαν· πολλοῖς δὲ καὶ τῶν ποιητῶν ἐν ἀηδόνος μνήμῃ Δαυλιὰς ἡ ὅρνις ἐπωνόμασται. (Cf Hesych. Δαυλία κορώνη; also Etym. M. p.250, δ Δαυλίαν κορώνην, ἀντὶ τὸν ἀηδόνα, ʼἈριστοφάνης διὰ τὸν μῦθον· ἔνιοι τὴν δασεῖαν). In the above passage from Thucydides the commentators take αἱ γυναῖκες to refer to Procne and Philomela; it seems to me to mean simply that in that spot the women-folk practised the rites of Adonis. I0 is noteworthy that Dodwell found an archaic village-festival, or feast of tabernacles, taking place at Daulis, when he visited the locality at the season of the vernal equinox (cf. Ε2ek. viii, ἄc.). The passage in Theocr. xV. 121 οἶοι ἀηδονιδῆες ἀεξομένων ἐπὶ δένδρων, κ..., with its context, is important in this connexion. As I have attempted to bring ἀηδὼν, Iys or Itylus, and possibly even Thamyras intο relation with Α G1ΟssΑRY ΟF GREEK BIRDS κhΔ (cοaίίaed). Adοnis, Atys, and Thammux respectively, so I am tempted to see a connexion between a fourth Adonis-name, Aasi or Aasa, and the traditional etymology (δασίς) οf Aaalis. Again, is it certain that ἀτθῖς ἀηδὼν, a late and rare epithet in Greek (Νonn. Dionys. xlii. 32, cf. ibid. xliv. 265), means really the Aiac nightingale; or may we not here also have an Atys-name? Lastly, a reference to a Moloch- sacrifice is indicated in Hesychius under the heading Δίβυs τε ἀηδὼν· αἱ γὰρ ἐν αρχηδόνι (τῆς Λιβύης δέ εἰσι) γυναῖκες [αἴ] τὰ ἴδια τέκνα κατά τι νόμιμον ἐσφαγίαζον Κρόνῳ [ςt maestis late loca questibus implent l]: cf. Soph. in Andromeda, fr. 132, ap.Hesych. s.v. κouρίον. Philomela and Procne are frequently confused, cf. Serv. ad Ecl. vi. 78. In all Greek authors, Philomel is the name of the Swallow, and Procne of the Νightingale (hr.Av. 665). The Latins generally reverse this; but Varro De L.L.and Virg.Εcl. vi adhere to the Greek version οf the story (W. 1.Τhompson, ad Plat.Gorg. fr. 6, p.180). ἀηδὼν and ἀλκυὼν are also apt to be confused, e.g. Arist.H.A.viii. 3, 593 b, where . MSS. have ἀηδόνων fοr ἀλκυόνων, and Suid. s.v. Τμερινὰ ζῶα, where ἀηδὼν οccurs among the θαλάσσια ζῶα, between dλκυὼν and κῆυξ; cf. Boch.Hieroz.ii.218. In the version of the Itylus-Myth given by Boios, ap. Anton. Lib. 11, the mother of Aedon is transformed into the bird ἀλκυών. See also s.vv. ἄλιάετος, ἄλκιών, χελιδών.

The metamorphosis of Aegypius and Νeophron into aἰγυπιοίʼ χρόαν δὲ καὶ μέγεθος οὐχ ὅμοιοι, ἀλλὰ ἐλάττων δρνις αἰγυπιὸς ἐγένετο Νεόφρων, Boios ap. Anton. Lib. Horap. αἰγυπιός is apparently the poetic name, applied to the various specis which frequent the battle-field, and on the other hand applied to an Εagle in such passages as Il. xvii. 46o. That the word is an old and antiquated one seems to be meant by Suidas : aἰγυπιόν· οὕτως οἱ παλαιοί, ἀλλʼ οὐ γῦπα. Cf Bekk.An.354. 28, Εutherford, Νew Phryn. p.19.

μf'Yt. A poetic word, of uncertain or indefinite meaning. Probably a large Gul, 6.g. Aars aaaraas, the Black-backed Gull (8undevall), or A. aνεatαίa., the Herring Gull (Κruper), the former being rare in Greece. Νetolickaʼs hypothesis of the Merganser, and that of Groshans that it was a Diver or Grebe, do not tally with Αristotle : Schneiderʼs identification with the Skua, Aesaris ;arasilicas, fails, inasmuch as the latter does not dive (vide Buchhol,op.C. pp. 112, 113) nor does it breed in the Mediterranean. The Herring Gull is abundant during the winter and breeds about the middle of April: the Common Tern (δcera aagίca) lays about the same time (κriper) but in the lagoons and not on the cliffs. Pr. 683. Mentioned also Eubul. fr. iii. 268, ap. Athen. ii. p. 65, Plut. ii. 537 B, and by Hesych. as στρουθοῦ γένος. The description in Arist.H.A.ix. 13 has suggested to scientific com- mentators (Sundevall, p. 116, ἄc.) the nest of the Long-tailed or Pendu- 1ine Tits, Aeihαίas cadaίas or 5eadaliaas (cf. αἰγίθαλος) οr Bearded Tit, Claaaahilas ὀiarπicas; but the neat round nest of the Goldfinch would suit the description well enough. The alternative form dκανθαλίς is evidently identical with dκαλανθίς, and so supports the identity of the bird with ἀκανθίς, while its identity with ποικιλίς, also asserted by the Schol. in Theocr., is strengthened by the statements of hostility to κορυδαλός in the case of both these birds. The latter statement is, of course, fabulous or mystical. In identifying ἀκανθυλλίς with the Gold- finch, I only mean that such an identification was probably adopted by Αristotle: what ἀκανθυλλίς, ἄνθος, ἄc. originally meant is unknown. See also αὶίθαλος, ἄνθος.

Ael. xvii. 46 αἱ μέν οὗν ἄλεκτορίδες ἐν τῷ τῆς βης νέμονται νεῷ, οἱ δὲ ἐν Τρακλέους οἱ τῶνδε γαμέται: cf Plut.ii.696 Ε, Paus. ii. 148. Αεl. Ν. A. ii. 30, how a new-purchased cock, if carried thrice round the table, does not seek thereafter to escape. Ib. iii. 31, how the lion fears the cock, and how the latter frightens the basilisk to death: for which reason travellers in Libya take a cock along with them. Cf ibid. vi. 22 ἔχθιστα δὲ τῷ μέν λέοντι πῦρ καὶ ἀλεκτρυὼν: Aes. Fab. 323; Plut. De Inv. iv (Mor. 650, 5), Sol. Anim. xxii (Mor. 1201, 23). In all the above references, as in most passages relating to the Εagle, a mystical and symbolic meaning outweighs the ioological. The poem οf Ciris is of great importance for the understanding of the myth. I0 is noteworthy how many birds, or names associated with birds, occur, with more or less obscure significance, in this poem; to wit, Procne, the Daulian maids, Pandion, the Aaser Aeaae, Haliaetus or Νisus, and lastly Ciris. I accept the theory that we have here to do with an elaborate Sun and Moon myth. The golden or purple lock in Nisusʼ hair (cui splendidus ostro Inter honoratos medio de vertice canos Crinis inhaerebat, Οv. Meu. viii. 8, cf. Ciris 22, Apollod. ii. 4. 5. recalls, on the one hand, the Samson-legend (as we are expressly told by T2etes in Lyc. 648), and on the other, the crest of the solar ἔποψ or ;icas, both of which birds appear in the version of the legend given by Boios. The name Nisus is akin to aesher, aisr, an eagle (vide Α GLΟSsΑRY or GREEK BIRDS ΑλlhffΟΣ (cοπίίνεd). s.v. ἀετόώ), and Νisus or Ἀλιάετος plunges, like the setting Sun, into the sea. Ciris, kεῖρις (with which I believe κείρυλος or κήρυλος to be connected), or Scylla is the Moon (cf. Porphyr.De Abst. iii.17), which, as the watery goddess, appears in some forms of the lgend as a fish. The last lines of the poem Ciris are of peculiar importance, where the mutual pursuit and flight of Haliaetus and Ciris are described,and com- pared with the alternate appearance and disappearance of the opposite constellations of Scorpio and Οrion: Quacunque illa levem fugiens secat aethera pennis, Ecce inimicus atrox magno stridore per auras Insequitur Νisus: qua se fert Νisus ad auras, Illa lvem fugiens raptim secat aethera pennis: i is the Moon in opposition, the Moon at the full, which (strictl speaking, at the sacred season of the equinox) sets and rises as the Sun rises and sets. Cf. also Cornutus, p.72 L (teste Κeller) κυνηγίᾳ δʼ ἕοικε καὶ τὸ μὴ διαλείπειν αὐτὴν ὀτὲ μέν διὼκουσαν τὸν ξλιον ὀτὲ δὲ φεύγουσαν .. .οὐχ ἐτέρα δʼ οὔσα αὐτῆς ἡ Τκάτη, ἄc. The full understanding of the stories of ἀηδὼν, Procne, Philomela, and the whole Tereus-legend, 6epends on the firther elcidation of this myth. Were it not for the comparison drawn with Scorpio and Οrion, we might be rather disposed to refer the description to the Moon in the last quarter, stationed in advance of and as it were in flight before the Sun. The same four lines occur in Virg. Georg. i. 406-4099, where I venture to think they are out of place and keeping.

The above state- ments have no 2oological significance: the Κingfisher neither breeds at four months old, nor lays five cggs (but rather six or seven), nor nests in the winter season, nor on the sea. I conjecture that the story originally referred to some astronomical phenomenon, probably in connexion with the Pleiades, of which constellation Alcyone is the principal star. In what appears to have been the most vigorous period of ancient astronomy (not later than 20oo B.C., but continuing lng afterwards to influence legend and nomenclature), the sun rose at the vernal equinox in conjunction with the Pleiad, in the sign Taurus: the Pleiad is in many lnguages associated with bird-names (cf. Εngl.'hen- and-chickens,' see also s. V. gpo], and I am inclined to take the bird on the bulls back in coins of Εretria, Dicaea, and Thurii for the asso- ciated constellation of the Pleiad. (Νote, as a coincidence, the relation οf Alcyoneus to the heavenly Bull in Pind.I. v.47; ubi Schol. βουβόταν δὲ τὸν βουκόλον φησί, παρʼ οὗ τᾶς Τλίου βοῦς ἀπήλασε ... The particular bird thus associated with Taurus may vary; on some of the above- mentioned coins, where it is certainly not a Κingfisher, it is taken by Canon Tristram (Ibis, 18931 p. 215) to be a Tern; to me it seems rather to be the Swallow, figuring as the bird of spring; (on the CΟgnate symbolism of the Dove, see s.v.ππέλεια). The Halcyon is said by Canon Tristram (l. c.) to have been the sacred bird of Εretria; I cannot find a direct statement of the fact. Suidas definitely asserts that the Pleiades were called Ἀλκυόνες. At the winter solstice, in the same ancient epoch, the Pleiad culminated at night-fall in mid-heaven, a phenomenon possibly referred to in the line νὺξ μακρὴ καὶ χεῖμα μέσην δʼ ἐπὶ Πλειάδα δύνει. This culmination,between three and four months after the heliacal rising of the Pleiad in Autumn, was, I conjecture, sym- bolied as the nesting of the Halcyon. Οwing to the antiquity and corruption of the legend, it is impossible to hazard more than a very guarded conjecture; but that the phenomenon was in some form an astronomic one I have no doubt. [It might for instance refer more directly to the Sun, which anciently began its annual course at the spring equinox when in conjunction with the Pleiads, and which at the winter season, when in the lowest part of its course, might be said to brood upon the sea, only beginning its ascent a week after the actual Α GLΟSSARY Ο oREER BIRDS μλYΚ (cοatiaaed). tοpic (cf. Ptolemy, ap. Petav. iii. 54, al. ]an.: Sol elevari incipit)]. The risings and settings of the Pleiads and of the Dogstar were apparently the chief lndmarks of the ancient yenr, and in this con- nexion the comparison with ἀλοσάχνη is also suggestive. I take ἀλοσάχνη to be a corruption, by 'Volksetymologie, of the Egyptian σολεχήν, the Dog-star. Cf Chalcid. in Timaeum Plat. f. cxxiv, ed. Fabr., Cum hanc eandem stellam ἀστροκνον quidam, Aegyptii vero σολεχήν vοcant (v. ablonsk. in Steph. Thes. and cf. Leemans in Horap. i. 3). The common Egyptian name for the Dog-star is Solha, and of this we read in Plut. De Isid. p. 375 Σωθι Alγυπτιστὶ σημαίνει κύησιν ἢ τὸ κύειν. The birds anciently associated with the season of the vernal equinox are, with the exception of the Nightingale, associated with St. Martin in modern times; vi. the House-martin or Martlet (df. χελιδὼν), the Harrier (cf. κίρκος), Fr. oiseau St. Martin, and the Κingfisher, Fr. martin-pecheur. It is precisely the same birds, with the addition of the solar Hoopoe and Woodpecker, and with the substitution of ἀλιάετος (q.v.) for κίρκος, that fgure together in the story of the meta- morphosis of Pandareus; Boios ap. Anton. Lib. Met. xi. In the calendars ascribed to Geminus (?), Columella and Ptolemy (?), the Halcyon days are placed in the end of February or beginning of March. I cannot account for this discrepancy, which is clearly at vwariance with the older tradition; unless indeed the phrase had lst its meaning and was simply transferred to the season of the migration οf birds. See also s.vv. ἀηδών, ἄλιπορφυρίς, κηρύλος, κῆιξ. Λa. - Οn the mystical element in the stories of dλκυὼν and ἀηδὼν cf. Lucian, Halc. οὐκ ἄν ἔχοιμεν εἰνεῖν βεβαίως οὔςʼ Ἀλκυόνων πέρι, οὔτʼ Ἀηδόνων· κλέος δὲ μύθων, οἶον ππαρέδοσαν πατέρες, τοιοῦτο καὶ παισὶν ἐμοῖς, δ ὅρνι θρήνων μελῳδέ, παραδώσω τῶν σῶν ὑμνων ππέρι, καί σου τὸν εὐσεβῆ καὶ φίλανδρον ἔρωτα πολλάκις ὑμνήσω.

Plin. x.74 (95). Wirh the above fabulous account, cf. Ael. H. A. v. 48, vi. 19 ἰδιάζει δὲ ταῖς μιμήσεσι τῶν τοιούτων ὅ,τε ἄνθος καλοὺμενος .. . . καὶ ὁ μέν ἄνθος ὑπποκρίνεται χρεμέτισμα ἵππου. Αlso Plin. x. (47) 52; see also Boios ap. Anton. Lib. c. 7, where Αnthus is a son of Autonous and Hippodameia, killed by his fathers horses, and metamorphosed into the bird ἄνθος. In Phile 7οy it is the fish ἀνθίας that is said to be hostile to the horse. Λοte. -As indicative of the mythical, fabulous, and probably exotic element in the above, compare the accounts of ἄνθος and ἀκανθίς (? ἀκ-ανθ-ίς), the former σκωληκοφάγος, εὐβίοτος, χρόαν καλός, ἵππῳ πολέμιος : the latter ἀκανθοφάγος, κακόβιος, κακόχροος, δνῳ πολέμιος, ἄC.2 ἀκανθίς and αἶγιίν)θος are perhaps two corruptions of the same word. Τhοugh the bird cannot be identified, and though it is more than doubtful whether it was ever known to the Greeks, yet Sundevalls identification of ἄνθος as the Yellow Wagtail, Aotaaala fav, La deserves to be recorded. This hypothetical identification is based on the brilliant colour (which according to v.d. Muhle is more brilliant in Greece even than in N. Εurope) and on the localities frequented. The Yellow Wagtail frequently consorts with the cattle at pasture, feeding on flies; it may indeed have become associated with the above fable, the origin of which, however, is doubtless more deep-seated and obscure.

L.i. 16.6, Paroem.Οr.i.p.307, ii. pp. 16,212 (Scaliger im Prov. metricis). Ar. Vesp. 257 τὸν πηλὸν ὥσπερ ἀτταγᾶς τυρβάσεις βαδίζων. Proverbial as a delicacy: Ar.ελαργοῖς in Athen. 388 b iτταγᾶς ἤδιστον ἔψειν ἐν ἐπινικίοις κρέας. Phoenicid. 4. ‖09 κοὺδέν ἦν τούτων πρὸς ἀτταγῆνα συμβαλεῖν τῶν βρωμάτων. Martial, xiii. 61 Inter sapores fertur alitum primus,Ionicarum gustus attagenarum. Cf. Οvid,F.vi.175, Hor. Epod. ii. 54; Plin. X. 48; Apicius, De e Coquin. vi. 3; Aul. Gell. Νοct. Att. vii. 16, δc. Mentioned also, Hippon. fr. ap. Athen.1 c. The Francolin does not now occur in Greece or Ialy, though it is found in Crete, Cyprus, Sicily, Malta, and on the southern shores of the Black Sea (Lindermaycr p. 125). Οn this account, Sundevall and others have disputed its identity with ἀτταγάς, and have identified the latter with various birds, especially Aerias ciaerea, the Common (or Νorthern) Partridge; C.T. Νewton, Cont Bev. 1876, p. 92, tmking it to be Alerοcίes alchala, a species of Sand-grouse. The descriptions, especially that of Alex. Myndius, point distinctly to the Francolin, and even Lindermayer does not doubt that the name is to be so interpreted, and that the bird was formerly abundant. The record by Sibthorpe of the modern Greek name, which I cannot find in more recent writers, suggests that the bird has only lately disappeared from Greece. According to Danford (Dresser, Birds of Εurope, vi p. 124) it is fast disappearing in hsia Minor also: likewise in Cyprus (Guille- mard, The Field, Sept. 892). The general disappearance of the Quail in recent years from England is a parallel case.

Αkad., 1876, p.78; the hawk enters as a phonetic or alphabetic element into the hieroglyphic spelling of ὄar or δα, and in the second place becomes associated with the symbolic meaning of the word. I suspect that βαίβυκος is closely allied, especially as a bird like a pelican is figured instead of a hawk in an alternative spelling of the syllable a. The Egyptian representation of the Soul as a Hawk is also mentioned by Chaeremon, ψυχή-λιος-θεόςςίέραξ; it, and the Harpy-figures which represent the disembodied soul are interesting in connexion with Plat Phaedr. p. 246; cf. ]omard, Descr. de lg. The Crane is in Greece a bird of pas- sage only, chiefly seen on is journey northward in the sping (cf. Strab.i. 2.28): it breeds further north, in Macedonia (hence μτaeς δaποπνν, Virgil, Seneca, Martial, Claudian, ἐc.; s. Aar- Δπνε, Antip.Sidon.cv, Lucan, 8c. and on the Danube (Κrtper, p. 267). A. i. 1, 488, iv. 12, 597 b; πολιτικὸν καὶ ὑφʼ ἡγεμόνι, i. 1, 488. Pugnacity: fights with tme eagle, I. xv. 692, Q. Smyrn. xiii. 104, Ael. iii. 13; and with its own kind, H. A. ix. 12, 615 b. Its flight is lofty, οὐρανόθι πρό, 11. iii. 3; cf. Hes. Οp. 446 εὗτ ἂν γεράνου φωνὴν ἐπακούσῃς, ψοθεν ἐκ νεφέων ἐνιαύσια κεκληγυίης (with which cf. Pind. Νem. vii εἴ τι πέραν ἀερθεὶς ἀνέκραγον); Aes. Fab. 397 ἄστρων ἔγγυς ἵπταμαι, Arist. H. A. ix. 10, 614 b, Avian. Fab. xv Ast ego deformi sublimis in aera penna, Proxima sideribus numinibusque feror; Ael. iii. 14, Plin. 1. 23, lsidor. Οrigin. xii. 77; see also Horap. ii. 98, where a watcher of the stars is said to be symbolied in Egypt as a crane, ὑψηλῶς γὰρ πάνυ ἵπταται, ἴνα θεάσηται τὰ νέφη, μὴ ἄρα χειμὰή, ἴνα ἐν ἡσυχίᾳ διαμένῃ: flies against the wind, Arist. H. A.viii. 13, 597. Lays two cfgs, ib. ix. 12, 615 b; oὐ συγκαθείσης τῆς θηλείας ἐπιβαίνει τὸ ἄρρεν, ib. v. 2, ‖39 b. igrations. - Arist. H. A. vviii. 12, ‖997 ἐκτοπίζουσιν ἐκ τῶν Σκυθικῶν πεδίων εἰς τὰ ἔλη τὰ ἄνω τῆς Alγύπτου (cf. Herod.ii.22). A fuller account, how they alight before foul weather, how they have in front a leader, καὶ τοὺς ἐπισυρίττοντας ἐν τοῖς ἐσχάτοις: how when sleping they stand first on one leg and then on the other: how while they rest the leader keeps watch, Αrist. H.A. ix. 10, 614 b: cf. frag. 241, 1522 a, Antig. H. Mirab. 46; and how their discipline taught men the rules of government, Ael.iii. 14. Cf in particular Eur. Hel. 1478 Λiυες οἰωνοὶ στολάδες δμβρον λιποῦσαι χειμέριον νίσσονται πρεσβυτάτᾳ σὺριγγι ππειθόμεναι πποιμένος, ἄ. Ηοw they fly aloft in the form of a triangle, with the old in front, the young in the middle, Ael. iii. 13, Plut. De Sol. Anim. Mor. 967 C, 979 A, Dion. De Αv. ii. 17, iii. 11. The distance they traverse, crossing the Euxine between the promontories of Crinmetopon and Carambis, Plin. x. 30: from Thrace to the river Hebrus, Ael. ii. 1; cf. Diog. Perieg. 155 αἱ τʼ ἄμφω ξυνίασιν ἐναντίαι, οὐ μέν ἐοῦσαι ἔγγυθεν, ἀλλʼ ὅσον ὁλκὰς ἐπὶ τρίτον ἡμαρ ἀνύσσῃ. The migration from Thrace takes place τοῦ Maιμακ- τηριῶνος, Arist. H. A. viii. 12; φθινοπώρου ξδη μεσοῦντος, Ael. iii. 13. Τhe flock was supposed to represent a Δ or other letters; cf. Philostr. How each carries a stone, ὡς ἔχειν καὶ δεῖπνον καὶ πρὸς τὰς ἐμβολὰς τῶν ἀνέμων ἔρμα, Ael. ii. 1, cf. Antip. Sidon. cv, Ar. Av. 1137, 1429, Νonn. [In Plin. xxxvii. 72, the stone γερανῖτις is said to be so called from resembling the hue of the craneʼs neck.] How the oldest crane, having encircled the flock, dies and is buried, Ael. ii. 1. How they post sentinels, who hold aloft a stone for wakefulnessʼ sake, Ael. iii. 13, Plut. 3ol. Anim. x, Xix, Plin.2. 30, Phil. De An. Pr. xi. The stone still figures in heraldry as the crane and her 'vigilance. The crane an Egyptian symbol of vigilance, Horap. ii. 94. It observes the time of its coming, intelligent of seasons, Hes. A weather-pxophet. - A sign of early winter, or of storm, ἐὰν ππρωὶ πέτονται καὶ ἀθρόοι, καὶ ἐὰν ὑποστραφῶσι πετόμενοι, Τheophr. Sign. iii. 1, Geopon. i. 3. 12; cf. Hes. Οp.et D. 629, and the imitation of the line in Ar. Av.711; αἱ κλαγγαὶ καλοῦσιν ὅμβρους, Ael.i. 44; cf. Virg. Aen. x.265, Οeorg. i 351, 373, (cf. Miluon, 'Wih clang despise tme ground, under a cloud In prospect ). How mariners return to port i they see the cranes fiying the contrary way, Ael. iii. 14, cf. vii. 7. A sign of fair weather, καὶ δʼ ἄν που γέρανοι μαλακῆς ππροπάροιθε γαλήνης, ἀσφαλέως τανύσαιεν ἔνα δρόμον λιθα πᾶσαι, Arat. Phen. 1010; cf. Theophr. Mentioned as food, Plat. Polit. p. 114, Athen. p. 131, Plut. De Εsu Carn. ii : Plin. X. 30, Hor. Sat. ii. 8, 86, Epod. ii. 35, Apic. vi. 2. Its brain used as an aphrodisiac, Ael. i. 44. How captured, by means of a beetle inside a dry gourd, Dion. De Avib. iii. 11. Grues mansue- factae, Plin. H. Ν. x. 23. Their plmes carried in front of the shield by certain Eastern tribes, Herod. vii. 70; cf. iv. 175. The Dance called γέρανος, Plut. Theseus, Xi. 1. 9 D, Luc.Sal. 34, ]. Pοll. i. 20 (o). Perhaps described in Callim. Delian Hymn, 515, dc.; still danced in Greece under the name of κανδιωτής, vide uys, Voy. litter., lttre xiii; represented in Leroy, Euines des plus beaux monuments de la Grece (2nd ed.), p. 22, pl. x (Ricard, Vies de Plut. i. p. 137, 1629). The dictionaries usually say that the dance mimics the fagnt of the cranes, which is incorrect: the dancing οf Cranes may be seen in the opening of the year in any 2oological garden. Mοr.614 F). γ.καὶ λύκος, 276 b. γ.καὶ ταῶς, 397 (Babr.65). See also ὅγορ, σέρτηu.

Α LΟSSARY ΟF REER BIRDS The War of the Οwls and Crows: πολεμία γλαῦξ, κορώνη, ὀρχίλος. Arist. Η. A. ix. 1, 609 νύκτωρ ἐπιβουλεύει τοῖς cοῖς τῆς κορώνης, κ.τ.λ. Αel. iii. 9, Antig. Mirab. 57 (2), Plau Οd. et Inv. iw (Mor. 537 Ο). The story is oriental, and is one of the chief tales in the Mahabharata. Cf 1ndian Antiq. March, 1882, p. 87; also,'The Νight of Slaughter, by Sir Εd. Arnold. The account in ]ulian. Imp. Οrat. iv. 1499 suigests that the story is simply a parable of the Sun and Moon; vide infra. See also s.v. soρώrη. Cf Prov. ἄλλο γλαῦξ, ἄλλο κορώνη φθέγγεται· ἐπὶ τῶν ἀλλήλοις μὴ συμφωνούντων, Suid. Milks the ewes like a goatsucker: uses a bat's heart to keep away ants from its nestlings, Dion. De Avib. i. 15. Sacred to Demeter, Porph. De Abst. iii. 5. Νο Οwls in Crete. Ael. v. 2, xvii. 10, Arist. De Mirab. 124 (130), 83 (.), Plin.2. 29 (41) Fables of the very wise Οwl, Aes. 105, 106, from Dio Chrysost. xii, 1xxii. A fabled metamorphosis, Νicand.ap.Anton. Lib.10; s.v. 6iξα: see also Boios ap. Ant. Lib. 15. The allusion to the Οwl in Ar. Av. 358 is unexplained; it contains some obscure reference to the sacred χύτρα and probably to the feast οf the χiτροι. γαῦζ can scarcely be said to be a generic term, except in the sense that the Little Οwl, as the commonest species, is taken as typical οf the rest. I1 is still extremely common about Athens (cf. Ar. Av. 301 γλαῦκʼ εἰς Ἀθήνας, cf. Antiph.3, 96 (Meineke), Lucian, Νigr. 1, Diog. 1a Vir. Plat., Cic. ad Quint. ii. 16, ἄc.; Propert. ii. 20, 5 nocturna volucris funesta querela, Attica), as indeed it is, in one or other of its 1ocal forms, all round the Levant. It is the bird of Athene (cf. Ar. Av. 516, Eq. 1092, ἅC. ἄε., doubtless in her primitive character of the Goddess of Νight; the epithet γλαυκῶπις is quite obscure, but I fancy we have it used in a very ancient sense when applied to the moon, C.f. Εur. fr. (ap. Schol. Ap. Rhod.i. 1280) γλαυκῶπίς τε στρέφεται μήνη : cf. Εmped. ap. Plut. ii. 934 C; cf. also γλαυκώ, a name for the Moon, Schol. Pind. Οl. vi. 76 (ciu. Fick, Beitr Indog. Spr. X, p. 156, 1894l. Οn Athene as a moon-goddess, cf. Porph. ap. Εuseb. P. Ε. iii. 11; Creuer, Symb. iii. 38o, ἄc. It was represented on Athenian coins (γλαῦκες Δαυριωτικαί, Ar. Av. 1106, Schol. in Ar. Εq. 1091, Plut. i. 443, Philochori fr. p. 83, Suid., Hesych.), and is still ume citys badge. Οn a very ancient colossal Οwl from the Parthenon, see Friederichs, Bausteine, p. 22; cf. Hesych. γλαῦξ ἐν πόλει· παροιμία, ἀνακεῖται γὰρ ὑπὸ Φαίδρου ἐν τῇ ἀκροπόλει. The οwl of Athene is always a hornless, and never a horned or eared species (cf. Blumenbach, Sp. Hist. Νat. Ant. p. 20, 6ttingen, 1808). Α dance called γλαῦξ, Athen. xiv. 629 f.; also σκώψ, q.V.

rVʼ, A Vuture. See also dετός, αἱγυππιός, νέρτος, ππερκνόππτερος, φήνη. Mοd. Gk. δρνεον, ἀγιοῦπα (yzantios). Frequent in Homer, usually with the idea of feeding on carrion, 11. iv. 237, Xi. 162, Vi. S36, Xii. 42; Οd. ii. 30, 4c. Cf Eur. Tr. 595 αἰματόεντα σὼματα νεκρῶν γυψὶ φέρειν τέταται: Εur. Rh. ‖ 15 πετεινοῖς γυψὶ θοινατήριον. Οv. Tr. vi. 11, Lucret. iv. 68o, Sil. 1al. iii. 396, c. sed metaphorically, Eur.Andr.75. fY (cοaίiaaed). Α GLΟSSARY ΟF GREEK BIRDS Αrist. H. A. vi. ‖, 563 νεοττεύει ἐπὶ πέτραις ἀπροσβάτοις (also Antig. H. Mirab.42 (48), cf.Aesch.Suppl. 7796 κρεμὰς γυπιὰς πέτρα)· διὸ σππάνιον ἰδεῖν νεοττιὰν γυπὸς καὶ νεοττούς. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο καὶ Ηρόδωρος ὁ Bρύσωνος τοῦ σοφιστοῦ πατὴρ φησὶν εἶναι τοὺς γῦπας ἀφʼ ἐτέρας γῆς, ἀδήλου ἡμῖν, τοῦτό τε λέγων τὸ σημεῖον, ὅτι οὐδεὶς ἐώρακε γυπὸς νεοττιάν, καὶ ὅτι πολλοὶ ἐξαίφνης φαίνονται ἀκολουθοῦντες τοῖς στρατεὺμασιν [as the Griffon Vulure did at Sebastopol], cf. Ael. ii.46, Basil. Hexaem. viii iδοιc ἐν μυρίας ἀγέλας γυπῶν τοῖς στρατοπέδοις παρεπομένας: ἄc. How the Vultures divine beforehand the place of battle, πρὸ ἡμερῶν ἐπτὰ ἐπʼ αὐτὸν παραγινόμεναι, Horap. i. 11; cf. Ael. ii. 46; Umbricius ap. Plin. x. ()7; Plaut Truc.ii. 3. 16, Martial, Ep. 62, 6. Αrist.l.c. τὸ δʼ ἐστὶ χαλεπὸν μέν ἰδεῖν, δπται δʼ ὅμως. τίκτουσι δὲ δύο cὰ οἱ γῦπες (cf. Plin. x.7). Cf. 1. A. ix. 11, 615, which latter passage has ἐν cὸν δύο τὰ πλεῖστα. On the mythical generation of vultures, how they are all femals, are impregnated by the East wind, lay no cgis, and bring forth their γoung alive and feathered, see Ael.ii.46, Arist. De Mirab.(6o) S35 a, 1. Horap. i. 11, Dion. De Avib. i. 5, Phile, De An. Pr. 121, Plt. Quaest. de Us. Εom. 93 (Mor. 286 A, B), Ammian. Marcell. xvii, Taeu Chil. xii. 4399, Euseb. Pr. Εv. iii. 12, and innumerable other references in Patristic literature. Οn the mythical genealogy of the vultures, see also s. vV. ἀετός, ἄλιάετος, φήνη. Τhese are Egyptian myths. Palar falvμs was sacred to Maut, the Goddess of Maternity, cf. Deut. xxii. 11, 12; cf. Horap. i. 11 μητέρα δέ γράφοντες γύπα ζωγραφοῦσι, ἐπειδὴ ὄρρην ἐν τούτῳ τῷ γένει τῶν ζcων οὐχ ὑπάρχει. Hence also the obstetrical value of a Vulure's feather, Plin. xxv. (4l 44. The Common Egyptian Vulture or Pharaohʼs Hen, Aeag.aοa perτadpcerus, was sacred to Isis, cf. Ael.x. 22 Aiγύπτιοι δὲ ρας μέν ἰερὸν ὅρνιν εἰναι πεπιστεύκασι τὸν γῦπα, κοσμοῦσι δὲ τὴν τῆς Τσιδος κεφαλὴν γυπὸς πτεροῖς. In Horapollo, γύψ is always feminine. The Vulture being sacred in Egypt, was an unclan bird among the ]ews; cf. ἔπποψ. Οn the φιλοστοργία οf the Vultures, cf. Οd. xvi. 216, Aesch. Ag. 49, Plut. Q. om. Mor. 286 A, B, Οpp. 1al. i. 723; cf αἱγοπιός. The Vulture is stated to feed its young with its own flesh or blood, a myth afterwards transferred to the Pelican; Horap.i. 11, cf. Georg. Pisidas, 1064 (cit. Leemans) τὸν μηρὸν ἐκτέμοντες, ἡματωμένοις Γάλακτος ὀλκοῖς ζωπυροῦσι τὰ βρέφη. Οn the connexion between the Vulture and the Pelican, see s.v. 6aιή6. The stories of the Vultureʼs tenderness and affection coincide with the resemblance between the Hebrew words ffI compassion, and bξ7 a vulture (Boch. Hieroz. ii. 8o3, cc.). How a Vultureʼs feather, if burnt, drives serpents from their holes, Αεl. i. 45, Plin. xxix. (a) 24. How the pomegranate is fatal to vultures, Αel. vi. 4. Howthe odour of myrrh is fatal to Vultures, Ar. De pYu (cοatiaaed). Mirab. (47) 8a5 a, 35, Ael. iii. 7, iv. 18, Geopon. xiii. 16, xiv. 26, Theοphr. De C. Pl. vi. 4, Clem. Alex. Paedag. ii. 8; and why, Dion. De Avib. i. 5. Doves do not fear the Vulture, Ael. v. 50; the hawk is hostile to it, Ael. ii. 42. Most of the above mythical attributes of the Vulure are summed up by Phile, c. iii De Vulture. The stories of Prometheus and Tityus, Οd. xi. 577; Aen. vi. 595 1 Lucret. iii. 997; Οv. Meu. iv. 456; Val. Fl. Angon. vii. 357, 4c. See also s.v. ἀετός. How the Persians exposed their dead to the Vultures, Herod. i. 140. Cf Ael. x. 22 Bαρκαῖοι (s. Bακκαῖοι, Ἀσσπανίας ἔθνος, Steph.) τοὺς ἐν πολέμῳ τὸν βίον καταστρέψαντας γυψὶ προβάλλουσιν, ἰερὸν τὸ ζῷον εἶαι πεπιστευκότες (cf. Sil. Ial. iii. 340, xiii. 470). The auguy of Romulus, Plut. Εomulus ix, Quest. Rom. 93, Dio Cass. Xvi. 46, Dion. Hal. i. p. 73, Ael x. 22, Liv. Hist. i. 7, 4c.; of Augustus, Sueton. Aug. C. 95. The prophecy of Vettis, drawn from the vultures of Romulus, as to the duration of Rome, Censorin.xiv. The Vulture is sacred to Hercules, Plut. Mor. 286 A; is associated wih Pallas, Εur.Τr. 594. The Vulture and Scarab together, according to their order and position, represented Νeith or Phtha, Athene or Hephaestus, Horap. i. 12; cf.Creuer, Svmb. iii.338,and Lauth op.cit. In the system of Egyptian hieroglphics the Vulture and the Beetle are associated or contrasted with one another. This relation bears upon certain statements made by Greek writers. The beetle, κάνθαρος, is devoid of females (Ael. x. 15) as the Vulture is of males; it is killed, as is the Vulture, by the odour of myrrh (Ael. i. 38, vi. 46, Phile 20, 1215); it shares with the 'Eagle the gift of tme renewal of youth (Arist. H. A. viii. 17, 601). For frther details concerning Egyptian Vulture-myths and for many references to other sources of information, see Horap. ed. Leemans, pp. 171-191; and for the connexion between the statements of Horapollo and the phonetic value of the Vulture- symbol, see Lauth, Situngsber. Bayer. Akad. 1876, pp. S-83. Α fabled metamorphosis, Boios ap. Ant. Lib. 21 Ἀγριος δὲ μετέβαλεν εἰς γῦπα, πάντων ὁρνίθων ἔχθιστον θεοῖς τε καὶ ἀνθρώποις. Α medicinal application, Dioscor. ii. cap. De stercore : γυπὸς ἄφοδος ἀποθυμιαθεῖσα ἔμβρυα ἐκτινάσσειν παραδέδοται (a statement frequently made by the Arab Doctors, Bochart). For other medicinal uses of the vultureʼs liver, heart, and feathers, see Plin. xxix. (al 24, () 38, Galen iv. 8, Sext. Platon. ii. 2, Quint. Seren. c. 47, ἀc. Σroverbs.-γυππὸς σκιά· ἐπὶ τῶν μηδενὸς λόγου ἀξίων (cf. ὅνου σκιά], Suid.; the proverb may refer, on the other hand, to the shadow of coming events, in allusion to the Vultureʼs fabled prescience (vide supra; cf. also Erasm. in Proverbiis s.v. 2allaris aaara). θᾶττον ἂν γὺψ ἀηδόνας μιμήσαιτο, Luc. Pisc. 37. pu (cοatiaaed). Α GLΟSsΑRY ΟF GREEK BIRDS γύψ is, like αlγυπιός, a generic word for Vulture. In Arist. H. A. viii. 3, 592 b, two species are distinguished, ὀ μέν μικρὸς καὶ ἐκλευκότερος, ὁ δὲ μείζων καὶ σποδοειδέστερος. Four vultnres occur in Greece, 6ypaeίas δανδαίas, the Limmergeier, Palar falvas, the Griffon Vulture, P. ciae- rwas, the Black or Cinereous Vulture, and Aeophrοa 5ercaopieras. Sundevall and others have tried to apportion among these four the names φἠνη, περκνόπτερος, and the two varieties mentioned of γύψ. But I think it certain that here the small white Aecphrοa is meant as the one variety, and that the larger darker sort includes the other three. The true Vultures were usually spoken of as dark-coloured or black; .g. Plin.x. 6 vulturum praevalent nigri, cf. Phile 3o; juv.Sat. iii vulturis atri poena; Senec. in Thyeste, visceribus atras pascit effossis aves.

ΔPYΟKΟAκʼΤʼΣ. Also δρυηκολάπτης, δρυκολάπτης (Ar. Av. 48ο, 979), δρυκόλαψ (esych., δρυοκόπος (Arist. De Part. iii. 1, 662 b). Cf Sk.ἀπιgλαα (eler) Α Wοοdpeckοx. Mοd. Gk. ζχλιδάρα (v.d. Muhle). See also δρύοψ, τππνη, κελεός, ππελεκᾶν, ππιππώ. Αrist. H.A. viii. 3, 93, vide s.v. ππιπώ. 1. ix. 9, 14, a fll and accurate description: κόπτει δὲ τὰς δρῦς ὁ δρυοκολάπτης τῶν σκωλήκων καὶ σκνιπῶν ἔνεκεν, ἴνʼ ἐξίωσιν. ἀναλέγεται γὰρ ἐξελθόντας αὐτοὺς τῇ γλώττῃ· τ- πλατεῖαν δʼ ἔχει καὶ μεγάλην. καὶ πορεύεται ἐπὶ τοῖς δένδρεσι ταχέως πάντα τρόπον, καὶ ὕπτιος καθάπερ οἱ ἀσκαλαβῶται. ἔχει δέ καὶ τοὺς ὅνυχας βελτίους τῶν κολοιῶν ππεφυκότας πρὸς τὴν ἀσφάλειαν τῆς ἐπὶ τοῖς δένδρεσιν ἐφεδρείας· τούτους γὰρ ἐμπηγνὺς πορεύεται. ἕστι δὲ τῶν δρυοκολαπτῶν ἔν μέν γένος ἔλαττον τοῦ κοττύφου, ἔχει δʼ ὑπέρυθρα μικρά, ἔτερον δὲ γένος μεῖζον κόττυφος· τὸ δὲ τρίτον γένος αὐτῶν οὐ πολλῷ ἔλαττόν ἐστιν ἀλεκτορίδος θηλείας. νεοττεύει δʼ ἐπὶ τῶν δένδρων, ἐν ἄλλοις τε τῶν δένδρων καὶ ἐν ἐλαίᾳις ...καὶ τιθασσευόμενος δέ τις ξδη ἀμύγδαλον εἰς ῥωγμὴν ξύλου ἐνθείς, ὅπως ἐναρμοσθέν ὑπομείνειεν αὐτοῦ τὴν πληγῆν, ἐν τῇ τρίτῃ πληγῇ διέκοψε καὶ κατήσθιε τὸ μαλακόν. Cf. Arist. De Mirab. 13, S31 b: the hard bill οf the woodpecker, Arist. De Part. iii. 1, 662 b. Four well-defined species occur in Greece. (a) the Great Black Woodpecker, Aicas Aariias, which evidently answers to the last and largest variety mentioned above; (ὀ) the Green Woodpecker,A.λνils, Α GLΟSSARY ο GREEK BIDS ΔΟΟhafYHΣ (eοatiaad). with its close ally, A. cαaas; (c, d) the Greater and Lesser Spotted Woodpeckers, A. aacfr and aaaaor. The Green Woodpecker is described under the name κελεός, and accordingly Sundevall and others make the remaining two of the three Aristotelian varieties to be the Greater and Lesser Spotted Woodpeckers respectively. But as A. 2ίνπli, whether it had another name or not, would certainly be still classed as δρυοκολάπτης, it is better to take it as the middle- sied sort, uniting the Greater and Lesser Spotted Woodpeckers as the last and least variety. The Woodpecker is not in Greek, as it is in Latin (e.g. Οv. Met. xiv. 321, F. iii. 37. 54, Virg.Aen.vii. 191, Plin.x. 18 (2o), Plu Q. Bom. Xi. 268 F, Εomuls iv; Aug.Civ.Dei,xiii. 151, a bird of great mythological importance, though the Dryopes were probably, like the descendants of Picus, a Woodpecker-tribe. It figures in the oriental Samir-legend (vide s.v. ἔππου) in Ael. i. 45 as making its nest in a tree, and, by Virtue of a certain herb, removing a stone with which one shall have blocked up the entrance; cf. Plin. x. (8) 20, Xv. 5; Plut. p. 269; Dion. De Avib. i. 14; and is accordingly spoken of as a rival power to ἔποψ in Ar.Av.48o. Cf. Alb.Magnus, De Mirab. 1601, p. 225. See also Baring-Gould, Mytms of the Middle Ages, p.397. The Woodpecker and the Hoopoe come into relation also in the version of the Tereus- myth given by Boios ap. Anton. Lib. Met. 11, where the brother of Αὲdοn is transformed into the bird ἔποψ, and her husband into πελεκᾶν.

Av. 94, , 279; Οvid, Metam. vi. 671 cui stant in vertice cristae, Prominet immodicum pro lngo cuspide rostrum, Pln. x.(5) 36 cum fetum eduxere abeunt. Is destructive to bees, Phil. Vv, 237, 243, 260 τιὸ τιό ἄc., though incorporated in the same speech, are evidently from the nightingale and other birds behind the scenes: κικκαβαῦ, v. 261, is the owl's hoot. Νest.- Arist. H. A. vi. 1, 599 a μόνος οὐ ποιεῖται νεοττιὰν τῶν καθʼ ἐαυτὰ νεοττευόντων, ἀλλʼ εἰσδυόμενος εἰς τὰ στελέχη ἐν τοῖς κοίλοις αὐτῶν τίκτει, οὐδέν συμφορούμενος. I. ix. 15, 616 b νεοττιὰν ποιεῖται ἐκ τῆς ἀνθρωπίνης κόπρου. According to Heldreich (p. 38) the Hoopoe is a spring and autumn migrant through Greece, but does not now breed there: it however seems to breed in Macedonia and perhaps in Epirus (riper). The story of the nest ἐκ κόπρου ἀνθρωπίνης (also in Ael. Η. A. iii. 26) arises () from the Hoopoeʼs habit of seeking its insect food among dung (avis obscoeno pastu, Plin. H. Ν. x. 29; cf. Fr. coq puant, Germ. Κοthhahn, Stinkhahn, Mistvogel, c., and (2) from the nest having an evil smell from the accumulation within of excrement, and perhaps also from a peculiar secretion of the birds (see for scientific references, Αub. and Wimm. i. p. 91) 1yth and Llesend.- The Tereus-myth (see also s.v. dηδών, ἄλιάετος, χελιδφυ) Aesch. fr. 297, in Arist. H.A. ix. 49 B, 633 a (nore probably from the lost Saphocieaa tragedy of Tereus, cf. Schol. Ar. Av. 284, Welcker, Gr. Trag. i. 38a) τοῦτον δʼ ἐπόπτην ἔποπα τῶν αὐτοῦ κακῶν πεποικίλωκε κάποδηλὼσας ἔχει θρασὺν πετραῖον ὅρνιν ἐν παντευχίᾳʼ δς ἡρι μέν φανέντι διαπάλλει πτερὸν κίρκου λεπάργουʼ κ.τ.λ. Cf Arist. H. A. ix. 15, 617 a, and 49 B, 633 a τὴν ἰδέαν μεταβάλλει τοῦ θέρους καὶ τοὺ 1ειμῶνος, Plin. x. (30l 44. With the phrase ἐπόπτην τῶν αὐτοῦ κακῶν, cf. Plat. Phaedo p.86 A φασὶ διὰ λύπην ζδειν: also Ach. Tat. v. 5 ὀ Τηρεὺς ὅρνις γίνεταιʼ καὶ τηροῦσι ἔτι τοῦ πάθους τὴν εἰκόνα. Inn the use of the word ἐπόπτης, we have not merely a fanciful derivation of ἔποψ, but also an allusion to the mysteries. In this very obscure story we have frequent indications of confision between Hoopoe and Cuckoo, and the ametamorphosis' is in part connected with the resemblance between the Cuckoo and the Hawk; cf. Arist. vi. 7, Theophr. H. Pl. ii. 6, Geopon. Xv. 1, 22, Plin. H. Ν. x. S, 11. See also Lenz, Σoοl. d. Gr. u. E. p. 318. For the relations between Hoopoe and Cuckoo, der Κuckuk und sein Κuster, v. Grimm, D. M. p. 646, Grohmann, Aberglaube aus Bόhmen, Leipig, 1864, p. 68, ἄc. Οn the metamorphosis of the Cuckoo into a Hawk in Εnglish and German Folkc-lore, see Swainson, Provincial Νames of British Birds, p. 113. How the Hoopoe first appeared at Tereus tomb in Megara, Paus. i. 41, 9. The Tereus-myth also in Aesch. Suppl. 60, Apollod. iii. 14, Αch. Tat. v. 5, Οvid, Metam. vi, ἄc. ἔfΟu (cοπtaaed). Α LΟsSΑRY Ο REEK BIRDS On the Tereus-myth, and the mythology of the Hoopoe in general, see in particular Ε. Οder, Der Wiedehopf in d.gr. όage, hein. Mus. (Ν. F.), iiiii pp.541556, 1888. A weather-prophet, Horap. ii. 92 ἐὰν πρὸ τοῦ καίρου τῶν ἀμπέλων ππολλὰ κράζῃ, εὐοινίαν σημαίει. The same of the Cuckoo, Plin. 1. Ν. xviii. 249, Hor. Sat. i. 7, 30. With ep.aσιος, Anton. Lib.xi. Phil. De An. Pr. 667 φθίσις δὲ τοῖς ἔποψι δορκάδων στέαρ (also Αel.H.A.vi.46). I.724, uses ὄγρωστις as a remedy (cf. ορυδός). Ael. i. 35 places ἀδίαντον οr καλλίτριχον (cf. ἀετός) as an amulet in its nest or heals itself when injured, Horap. ii. 931 also written ἀμίαντον, eopon. xV. 1, 19. How the Hoopoe by means of a certain herb (the same ἀδίαντον) 1iberates its imprisoned young, Ael. iii. 26, cf. Ar. Av. 654, 655. The same story of Picus, Plin. Η. Ν. x. 18 (2o), vide s.v. bριοκολάππτης. This is a version of the well-known Samir-legend (the 'open Sesame' οf the Forty Thieves), and is told also of the Hoopoe in connexion with Solomon (Boch. Hiero. ii. 347). See also Buxdorf, Lex. Talmud. col. 2455 : on similar German superstitions see Meier, Schwab.Sagen, Νr. 265. Οn Indian vwersions of the story of the Hoopoe which shel- tered Solomon from the sun, see W. F. Sinclair, Ind. Antiquary, 1874, also ib. 1873, p. 229, Curionʼs Monast.of the Levant, c. xii, ἄc. The story of the Indian Hoopoe, Ael. xvi. 5, which buried its father in its head (vide s.v. aoροδός] is probably connected with the same lgend; see Lassen, lnd. Alterth. 2nd ed. i. p. 304. The statement (Ael. l.c.) that the ἔποψ Τνδικός is διπλάσιον τοῦ παρʼ ἠμῖν, καὶ ὡραιότερον ἰδεῖν, is purely fabulous. Filial affection of the Hoopoe, Ael x. 16, vide s.v. κouκούφα, ππάλαργός. Τhe Hoopoe on coins of Antoninus as a symbol of filial love, Εckhel, Doctr. numm. vi. 531, Creuer, Symbolik, ii. p. 64, οeger Νumm. Eg. 1mp. pl X. 1, Seguin.Scl. Νumism. p. 152. The evil smell of the Hoopoe suggests a connexion with Pitumnus in the story of Pilumnus and Pitumnus or Sterculinius; Serv. Aen.ix.4 fratres fuerunt dii; horum Pitumnus usum stercorandorum invenit agrorum, Οder,op.. p. 556: cf. ]ordan-Preller, Ε6m. Myth. i. 375. The Hoopoe was a sacred bird in Egypt, as it still is among the Αrabs (d. Creuer, l c., Denon pl. 119, δ, Cc., ἄc.. From its rayed crest it was a solar emblem, and it is in part as such that it comes into relation with κίρκος, the sacred hawk of the solar Apollo. The wood- pecker, with its red or golden crest (cf. Οv. Met. xiv. 394) becomes in like manner a solar emblem, and there is a curious parallel in the con- nexion between Carce and the metamorphosis of Picus. As a solar emblem also, the Hoopoe fgures in the version of the Phoenix-myth ἔfΟu (οπίίaεά). ἔfΟu-- ἔ5SμΟS in Ael. 1vi. 5. Tο a like source is traceable the Samir-legend, and possibly also the obscure origin of the Tereus-myth. From its sanctity in Egypt it became an unclean bird among the ]ews, Lev. xi. 19, Deut. xiv.16,where its name fiΣY iasφhat (cf. κousoύφα) is rendered Αcβwπνί, as being the crested bird with which the translators were most familiar (cf. Νewton, Dict.of Birds, p. 505). In the Birds of Aristophanes we have many veiled allusions to the mythology of the Hoopoe. The confusion with κόκκυξ (vide s. v. κοικούφα) is indicated throughout; the fables of Tereus and Procne are frequently referred to, .f. γὰρ ἄνθρωπος, v. 98 τὴν ἐμὴν ἀηδόνα, vv. 203, 367, ἄc.: the Hoopoeʼs first cry, ἄνοιγε τὴν ὕλην, . 93, is a reference to the Samir-legend; the kindred fable of κορυδός appears in vV.472-476; the mysterious root in v. 694 is the magical ἀδίαντον; the mention of ἡλιαστής, v. 109, is a pun on ἤλιος: the allied solar symbolism of δρυοκολάπτης is suggested in v. 48o; and the nauseous reputation of the nest is probably hinted at in the Hoopoeʼs pressing invitation to Peisthetairus, v. 641, that he should enter in.
ἈίsaκoΣ, ;. ἐριακός (Arist., Ael), ἐριεός (Arat., Theophr.), ἐρίθολος (8chol. ad Ar. Vesp.). The Bobn, Araacas aalecal, L. Arist. H. A. viii. 3, ‖92 b ὅρνις σκωληκοφάγος. ix. 49 B, 632 b μετα- βάλλουσιν οἱ ἐρίθακοι καὶ οἱ καλούμενοι φοινίκουροι ἐξ ἀλλήλων· ἔστι δʼ ἐ μέν ἐρίθακος χειμερινόν, οἱ δὲ φοινίκουροι θερινοί, διαφέρουσι δʼ ἀλλήλων οὐθέν ὡς εἰπεῖν ἀλλʼ ἢ τῇ χρόᾳ μόνον: Geopon. xV. 1. 22. Α weather-prophet, Arat. Phen. 1025, Theophr. fr. vi. 3, 2 χeadῶνος μέγα σῆμα καὶ ὅρχιλος καὶ ἐριθεύς, δύνων ἐς κοίλας ὀχεάς. Arist. fr. 2411 I522 b ἐρίθακος ἐς τὰ αὔλια καὶ τὰ οἰκούμενὰ παριὼν δῆλός ἐστι χειμῶνος ἐπιδημίαν ἀποδιδράσκων. Cf. Ael. vii.7. A 1mimetic bird, μιμοῦνται καὶ μέμνηνται δν ἂν ἀκούσωσιν, Porphyr. De Αbst. iii. 4 (ἐρίθακος here is either an interpolation, οr is used of some other bird). Proverb, Schol.in Ar. Vesp.922 (927) μία λόχμη δύο ἐριθάκους οὺ ττρέφει. ἔστι δὲ ὅρνεον ὑπὸ μέν τινων καλοὺμενον ἐριθεύς, ὑπὸ δὲ ἐτέρων ἐρίθυλος, ὑπὸ τῶν πλειόνων ἐρίθακος: cf. Photius. Also ἐριθεύς· ὀ ἐριθακός, τὸ δρνεον, Hesych. ἐρίθακος· ὅρνεον μονῆρες καὶ μονότροπον, Suid. Sundevall derives ἐρίθακος from ἐρυθρός, θᾶκος (cf. Εng. rslrr, Germ. Εothsteiss), and identifies the bird in Arist. with the Redstart, Αasciolα 5hoeaicars, L., in winter plmage : vide s.v. φοινίκοuρος. The derivation is far-fetched, and the identification is discountenanced by the fact that the Redstart does not, at last in Attica, remain through the winter (κriper p. 245), during which season the Robin is as common there as with us. See also αἱσακος, δάνδαλος.

Εrodius, who tended the horses of his father Autonous, was turned into the bird ἐρωδιός, his father being metamorphosed into ὅκνος, and the groom into ἐρωδιός. ἀλλʼ οὐχ ὅμοιονʼ ἤσσον γάρ ἐστιν ἰκανῶς τοῦ πελλοῦ: Boios ap. Ant. Lib. Met. 7. Swallows a crab, κάρκινον, as a remedy, Phile 724, or places one in its nest as a charm, Ael. i. 35, Geopon. xV. 1. Νoted, like the stork, for filial and parental affection, Ael. iii. 23. ΟΟn the painful generation of the Heron cf. Arist. H. A. ix. 1, 609 b, Plin.x. (o) 79; hence a fanciful derivation of ἐρωδιός in Εtym. M.and Εust. ad I1. x. 274. Vide infra, s. v. πέλλος. The Island of Diomedea, Ael. H. A. i. 1 καλεῖταί τις Διομήδεια νῆσος, καὶ ἐρωδιοὺς ἔχει πολλούς, and how these ἐρωδιοί, οnce the comrades of Diomede, give welcome to Greek visitors; also Lycus ap.Antig. Mirab. 172 (88), Anton. Lib. Met. 37, Phile, De Anim. Pr. 152. Cf Οvid, Metam. xiv.498, Aen.xi. 271 et Serv. in loc., Plin.x. 44 (61). Cf. also S.Augustin, De Civ. Dei, xviii. 16, Lachmund, De Ave Diomedea diss., Amstelod. (672) 1686. There is evident but obscure connexion between the story of the birds of Diomede, and the meta- morphosis above alluded to: where the son of Autonous and Hippo- dameia is killed by his fatherʼs horses, and his father and his servant are turned into ἐρωδιοί. A story similar to that of the birds of Diomede is wide-spread, and usually told of the Stork, cf. Alex. Mynd. ap. Ael. iii. 23; for Modern Greek references, see Marx, Gr. Marchen, 1876, p. 53, 95. See also ἄσιδον, ἀστερίας, ἔλώριος, λευκερωδιός, ὅκνος, ππέλλος.

Οf the two species of Ibis, the Wnite or Sacred 1bis, which was first recognied by Bruce (Travels in Abyss. v. p. 173, 1790) is αa- ἰlas αethiapicas, Latham, Aaaaeaias Ais, Savigny, or Iis rlgiosa, Cuv.: the Abou Hannes or Father ]ohn of the Abyssinians (Bruce), and Αbou Mengel or Father Sickle-bill of the fellaheen. The Sacred Iis still regularly visits Lower Egypt at the time of the inundation, coming from Νubia (cf. Newton, Dict. οf Birds, s.v.). Before the time of Bruceʼs discovery, the name had been variously assigned to several 1Bi (cοaίνπεά). SfPΟΟoΣ-18t birds : having been likened to a Stork by Stabo, it was identified with that bird by Belon, by Prosp. Alpin., Hist. Eg. Νat. p. 199, and by Caylus, Antiq. Ep. vii. p. 5a, tough such an identificatin was expressly rejected by (e.g.) Albertus Magnus (vi. p. 64o non est ciconia: quia rostrum longum quidem sed aduncum habet), and Vincent. Burgund., Bibl. Mund. i. p. 1212; it was supposed to be a Curlew (flaiaellas) by Gesner (H. A. iii. 546) and Aldrovandi (Οrn. iii. p. 312) and an Egret or Whire Heron by Hasselquist (Iter Palest. (2) cl. 2, no. 25), an identification adopted by Linnaeus (Syst. Νat. ed. X. p. 114); by Perrault (Acad. des 3c. Paris, iii. p. 55, pt. xiii) it was taken to be a much larger bird, the Iαaias ilir of Linnaeus (Syst. Νat. ed. xiil; and yet others, e. g. Maillet (Descr. de lEgypte, 4to ii. p. 22) confounded it with the Egyptian Vulture or 'Pharaohʼs Hen.' The Whire Ibis is figured on the Mosaic of Palestrina (cf. the coloured figures in the Pitture ant. di Petr. S. Bartholi) and in the Pitture ant. dʼ Εrculaneo (ii. pll. 59, 60). Herod. ii.75, 76 ἔστι δὲ χῶρος τῆς Ἀραβίης κατὰ Bουτοῦν πόλιν μάλιστά κη κείμενοςʼ καὶ ἐς τοῦτο τὸ χωρίον ἤλθον, πυνθανόμενος περὶ τῶν πτερωτῶν ὀφίων. . . λόγος δέ ἐστι, ἄμα τῷ ἔαρι πτερωτοὺς ὅφις ἐκ τῆς Ἀραβίης πέτεσθαι ἐπʼ Αlγύπτου· τὰς δὲ ἴις τὰς ὅρνιθας ἀπαντώσας ἐς τὴν ἐσβολὴν ταύτης τῆς χώρης οὐ παριέναι τοὺς ὅφις, ἀλλὰ κατακτείνεινʼ καὶ τὴν ἴβιν διὰ τοῦτο τὸ ἔργον τετιμῆσθαι λέγουσι Ἀράβιοι μεγάλως πρὸς Aἰγυπτίων. ὀμολογέουσι δὲ καὶ Alγύπτιοι διὰ ταῦτα τιμᾶν τὰς ὅρνιθας ταύτας. εἶδος δὲ τῆς μέν ἴβιος τόδε· μέλαινα δεινῶς πᾶσα, σκέλεα δὲ φορέει γεράνου, πρόσωπον δὲ ἐς τὰ μάλιστα ἐπίγρυπον, μέγαθος ὅσον κρέξ. τῶν μέν δὴ μελαινέων, τῶν μαχομένων πρὸς τοὺς ὅφις, δε ἰδέη. τῶν δʼ ἐν ποσὶ μᾶλλον εἰλευμένων τοῖσι ἀνθρὼποισι· (διξαὶ γὰρ δή εἰσι αἱ ἴβιες] ψιλὴ τὴν κεφαλήν, καὶ τὴν δειρὴν πᾶσανʼ λευκὴ πτεροῖσι, πλὴν κεφαλῆς καὶ τοῦ αὐχένος καὶ ἄκρων 18 (cοaίaaε). Α GLΟSSARY οr GREE BIRDS τῶν πτερύγων καὶ τοῦ πυγαίου ἄκρουʼ ταῦτα δὲ τὰ οἶπον ππάντα, μέλαινά ἐστι δεινῶς· σκέλεα δὲ καὶ πρόσωπον, ἐμφερὴς τῇ ἐτέρῃ. Cf. Arist. H. Many of the birdʼs peculiarities, real or fabulous, are mystically associated with the same god: e.g. its dainty walk (Ael. ii. 33) with the inventor οf the dance; its numerical constants (e.g. its intestine 96 cubits long, and its pace of one cubit, Ael. x. 29) with the inventor of arithmetic; the equilateral triangle or Δ that its beak and legs made (Plut. Is. et Οsir.381; or its legs alone, Pier. Valer.xvii. 18, xlii) with the inventor οf letters (cf. also Κircher, Οbel. Pamphil. pp. 125-131), is knowledge of physic with the founder of the medical art. Lond. 1749) : cf. Ν. and Q. (a) ix. p. 216: see also Bacon, De Augm. v. 2. The opposed black and white of the 1isʼ plumage, as sometimes of Mercuryʼʼs raiment, suggested various sym- bolic parallels, the opposition of male and female, of light and darkness, οf order and disorder, of speech and silence, of truth and falsehood: cf. Ael. x. 29, Schol. in Pl. Phaedr.. Pluut. De ls. 38 D, Clem. Alex. Str. V. 7. The 1bis is a symbol of the heart (περὶ οὖ λόγος ἐστὶ πλεῖστος παρʼ Alγυππτίοις φερόμενος, Ηorap. i. 36), an organ under the protection οf Hermes; ad the bird has a heart-shaped outline (Ael. x. 29 καρδίας σχῆμα, ὅταν ὑποκρύψηται τὴν δέρην καὶ τὴν κεφαλὴν τοῖς ὑπὸ τῷ στέρνῳ πτεροῖς) as indeed its mummies have still; a weight as it issues from the gg cqual to the heart of a new-born child (Plut. Symp. 670), or a heart of its own of exceptional sie (Gaudent. Merula, Memorab. iii. c. 50); in this connexion we may compare the Eg. αha with 6a or δαν the soul (Lauth, op. cit.); cf.supra s. v. aιής. The Ibis was em- blematic of the ecliptic or 1odiacal ring: ἀριθμοῦ γὰρ ἐπινοίας καὶ μέτρου μάλιστα τῶν ζόων ἡ ἴβις ἀρχὴν παρέχεσθαι τοῖς Alγυπτίοις δοκεῖ, ἐς τῶν κύκλων λοξός, Clem. Alex. Stromat. p. 671. It enjoyed freedom from sickness, lngevity, or even immortality (Apion ap. Ael. x. 29); it was buried at Hermopolis (Herod. ii. 67, Ael. l.c.)

ἈʼTμ (p. and Ion. ηξ, ηξ: ἴ). Νοt connected with lερός (); perhaps from root μῖ swift (cf. Maass, Indo-Germ. Forsch. i. p. 159), but the etymolgy is quite obscure. A Hawk. The generic term especially for the smaller hawks and falcons. Mod. Gk. iεράκι or γεράκι, applied to the Sparrow-hawk, Κesuεl, Hobby, λο. and also to the Eite (frhard). Dimin. ἔερακιδεύς, Eust. 753, 56; ρακίσκος, Ar. Av. 1112. In Hom. with epithets ὡκύς Il. xvi. 582, ὡκύπτερος xiii. 62, ὥκιστος πετεηνῶν xV. 237, ἐλαφρότατος πετεηνῶν xiii. 86: also Οd. v. 66. In Hes. Οp. et D. 210 ὡκυπέτης ἵρηξ, τανυσίπτερος δρνις: cf. Ar. Av. 1453. In Αrist. with ep. γαμψώνυχον, σαρκοφάγος, μοφάγος, ἄc. Alcman 16 ap. Αthen. 73 λῦσαν δʼ ἄπρακτα νεανίδες, στʼ ὅρνεις ἰέρακος ὑπερππταμένω : Εur. Andr. 1141 οἱ δʼ ὅπως πελειάδες ἰέρακʼ ἰδοῦσαι πρὸς φυγὴν ἐνώτισαν. Varieties.- Arist. H. A. ix. 6, 620 τῶν δʼ ἰεράκων κράτιστος μέν ὁ τριόρχης, δεύτερος δʼ ὁ αἴσάλων, τρίτος ὁ κίρκος· ὄ δʼ ἀστερίας καὶ ὁ φασσο- φόνος καὶ ὁ τέρνις ἀλλοῖοι· οἱ δὲ πλατύτεροι ἰέρακες ὑποτριόρχαι καλοῦνται, ἄλλοι δὲ πέρκοι καὶ σππιζίαι, οἱ δὲ λεῖοι καὶ οἱ φρυνολόγοι· γένη δὲ τῶν ἰεράκων φασί τινες εἶναι οὐκ ἐλάττω τῶν δέκα, διαφέρουσι δʼ λλήλων, κ.τ.λ. Cf ib. viii. 3, ‖92 b. That there were ten species of hawks is asserted by Callimachus, Etym. M. Vide Callim. fr. p. 468, ibique Bentleii; cf. Schol. ad Ap. Εhod. i. 1049. For lists of the species, cf. Ar. Av. 1178, Ael. xii. 4, Dion. De Avib. i. 6, Plin. 1. 8, 9, 10. The Egyptian hawks were smaller, Arist. H. A. xii. 4. A. vi. 7, 62 b, Plut. Arat. cap. XXx, T2et. ad Lyc. 395; eopon. xv. 1. Theophr. De Pl. ii. 41 4. Av. 516, Eq. 1052), καὶ τὸν μέν θεὸν Ὀρὸν καλοῦσι τῇ φωνῇ τῇ σφετέρᾳ . . . οἱ γὰρ ἰέρακες ὀρνίθων μόνοι ταῖς ἀκτῖσι τοῦ ἡλίου ῥᾳδίως καὶ ἀβασανιστῶς ἀντιβλέποντες, κ.τ.λ.: cf. ib. xi. 39 and vii.9, where the priests are called lερακοβοσκοί; cf. also Plut. Ael. xii. 4 ὁ μέν περδικοθήρας καὶ ὡκύπτερος Ἀπόλλωνός ἐστι θεράπων φασί, φήνην δὲ καὶ ἄρπην Ἀθηνᾷ προσνέμουσιν, Ἀρμοῦ δὲ τὸν φασσοφόντην ἄθυρμα εἶναί φασιν, Ἀρας δὲ τὸν τανυσίπτερον, καὶ τὸν τριόρχην οὗτω καλοὺμενον Ἀρτέμιδος. μητρὶ δὲ θεδν τὸν μέρμνον. See also Strabo, eogr. xvii. 1. 47, Horap. i. S, Pier. Valer. Hierogl. Xi, ἄC. τίνες δέ φασιν ἐν τοῖς ἀρχαίοις χρόνοις, ἰέρακα βιβλίον ἐνεγκεῖν εἰς 6Θήβας τοῖς ἱερεῦσι φοινικῷ ῥάμματι ππεριειλημμένον, ἔχον γεγραμμένας τὰς τῶν θεραπείας τε καὶ τιμάς· διόπερ καὶ τοὺς ἰερογραμματεῖ φορεῖν φοινικοῦν ῥάμμα καὶ πτερὸν ἱέρακος ἐπὶ τῆς κεφαλῆς, Diod. Sic. i. 8y, 8. The Egyptian Sun-god Phra with a hawks head, lsρακὸμορφος, lερακοπρὸσ- ωπος, Philo ap. Εus. P. Ε. 41 D, 16 D (i. 10, iii. 12), Horap. i. 6. In the Rig-Veda the sun is frequently compared to a hawk, hovering in the air. The hawk associated with fire-worship, Ael.x. 24. A three- legied hawk sometimes seen in Egypt, Ael. xi. 39. Moult before the inundation, ib.xii. 4; live seventy years, ib. x. 14; the leg-bone has an attraction for gold, ib.; throw earth on an unburied corpse, ib. ii. 42. Salve their eyes with θριδακίνη οr wild lettuce, ib. ii. 43 (also Dion. De Avib. i. 6); hence, as well as by reason of their sharp sight, the Hawk or Eagle in medicine constitute a remedy for diseases οf the eye, Plin. xxix. (6) 38, ἄc.; as does the herb lεράκιον, Horap. i. 6, Plin. xx. (7) 26, xxxiv. (1) 27: it is seldom possible to trace any meaning in the mystical herbs associated with particular animals. and it is therefore worth noting in this instance that θριδακίνη is the sacred herb of Adonis. Are supposed by some to be bastard eagles, Ael. ii. 43; how a hawk caused the apprehension of a sacrilegious thief at Delphi, ib.; how the hawks in Egypt repair to certain Libyan islands to breed, having sent two messengers in front, ib. (cf. Plin. H. Ν. x. S, Diod. Sic. i. 87); do not eat the heart, ib.ii.42; hostile to the fox, the eagle, and the lture, ib. Are exempt from thirst, Damasc. V. 1sid. 97 (cf. s.v. ἀετός), but drink blood instead of water, Horap. i. 7. Their 1ΡA (εοπtίaaed). 1Pa- TePΟΣ heart is eaten, t obtain prophetic powers, Porph. De Abst. ii. 48. A Hawk sitting on a tree a sigm of rain, Theophr. Sign. fr. vi. 2, 17. The Fable of tme Hawk and the Νightingale, Hes. Οp. et D. 201, Αes.fab. 9. Α metaphor of the Hawk and the Crows, Ar. Eq. 1052. The metamorphosis of Hierax, Boios ap. Anton. Lib. iii; cf. that of Deucalion, Οv. Met. xi. 340. The Hawk entered in Egypt into innumerable hieroglyphics, in which its image is, in the main, a phonetic element, the symbolic ideas being, for the most part, secondary (cf. supra, s. v. 5aιήθ). According to Horap. i. 8 Ἀρεα γράφοντες καὶ Ἀφροδίτην, δύο ἰέρακας ζωγραφοῦσιν; these are the symbols and , Horus and Hat-Hor, the latter being the οἴκος αρου οf Plutarch. According to Chaeremon, fr. 8 υχή-ξλιος-θεός - ἰέραξ. Οn the sanctity of hawks in Egypt, and the solar symbolism associated with them there, see also (besides the references quoted above), Porph. De Abst. iii. 4; the Sun called ἐραξ, ibid. iw. 16, Plut De Is. et Οsir. c. 51, Eus. P.Ε. iii. 10, Clem. Alex. Strom. v. 7. For other words and phrases in which the hieroglyph of the Hawk had part, see Horap. i. 6 θεὸν βουλόμενοι σημfναι, ἢ ὑψος, ἢ ταπείνωσιν, ἡ ὑπεροχήν, ἢ αἶμα, ἢ νίκην, έρακα ζωγραφοῦσι: id. ii. 15 ἐραξ διατεταμένος τὰς πτέρυγας ἐν ἀέρι, εον πτέρυγας ἔχοντα ἄνεμον σημαῖναι: id. ii. 999 ἄνθρωπον ἀπποταξάμενον τὰ ἴδια τέκνα διʼ ἀπορίαν βουλόμενοι σημfναι, έρακα ἐγκύμονα ζωγραφοῦσιν: Diod. Sic. iii. 4. 2 ἰέραξ αὐτοῖς σημαίνει πάντα τὰ ὀξέως γενόμενα. Cf. Κlaproth ad Goulianoff De Inv. Hierogl. Acrolog. cit.Leemans in Horap. p. 150, and especially Lauth, Situngsber.Bayer. ἈΣ οἱωνοί, δρνιθες, Hesych. Cf. ἀεινοί.
ἈτsΡΟΣ. A bird with fabulous attributes; according to Pliny, identical with ralalas, the 6olden Οriole. Plin. xxx. 11 (28) Avis icterus vocatur a colore, quae si spectetur, sanari id malum [ἴκτερον, νalνt rsgia, the jaundice] tradunt, et avem mori. Hanc puto Latine vocari galgulum (gaiόala, Mart. xiii. 68). Cf Dion. De Avib. i. 27; Coel. Aurel. Chron. iii. 5 passio vocabulm sumpsit secundum Graecos ab animalis nomine, quod sit coloris fellei. Cf.Schneider, in Arist.H.A.ix.12; and Suid., who derives the word from ἰκτῖνος. Vide infra s.v. 105αbρuός.
Α GLΟSSARY οr REER BIRDS ἈτίTοΣ, οr ἴκτινος (ristoph., cf. Suid.): also lrίς (fεργαοι,Hεςych.). In plr. ἴτινε (Ael. i. 35, i. 47) or ἰκτνεε (Paus.). For other grammatical forms, see L. Sc.. ἐc. Derivation unknown; sometimes said to be connected with Sk. yδna. A Lite : inclding the Common Κite, Aias aegαh, Briss.. A. aλλπσ, Sav., and tme Black Rite, A. aἰr, Gm. The Black ite is still caled lκτνος in the Cyclades, where it is the com- moner species of the two (Erh.). The Common Κite is also caled ττείφτης in Attica (Heldreicb). In minor references frequent, usually as a robber, 6.g.Theogn. I261, 1302; Soph.Fr.89o ἴκτινος ὡς ἔκλαγξε παρασύρας κρέας; Plat. Phaed.82; Men. 4. 329 (a93); Plat. Com. 2, 695 (9): Aristoph.fr. 2, 1192 (1), Αr. fr. 525, Etym. M. p. 470. 34 lκτινα παντόφθαλμον ἄρπαγα: Simon. Iambl. 11, Automed. viii, in Gk. Anth. ii. 192 οὔτος ἔχει γὰρ ἄρπαγο ἰκτίνου χεὶρα κραταιοτέρην. Dοsοription. λrist. De Part. 670, 34 μικρὸς ὀ σππλήν· τὴν χολὴν ἔχει πρὸς τῷ ἤπατι καὶ πρὸς τή κοιλίᾳ: H. A. vi. 6, y63 δύο cά· ἐνίοτε δὲ καὶ τρία· ἐππωάζει ππερὶ εἶκοσιν ἠμέρας: ib. viii. , ‖992 μέγεθος ὅσον τριόρχης 3 ib. 594 ὀλιγάκις πίνει, ὦπται δέ πίνων. Very destructive to poultry; οὐδέν ἄν τις ἀναιδέστερον εἶποι, Dion. De Avib. i. 7; cf. Theogn. 1302 ἰrίνου σχέτλιον ἦθος. Α migratory bird: it arrives before the swallow, at the spring shearing-time, Ar. Av. 714; in Egypt it does not migrate, Herod. ii. 22; it sometimes hibernates, Arist. H. A. viii. 16, 6oo οἱ μέν πλησίον ὅντες τοιούτων τόπων, ἐν οἶς ἀεὶ διαμένουσι, καὶ ἰκτῖνοι καὶ χελιδόνες, ἀπο- χωροῦσιν ἐνταῦθα, οἱ δὲ πορρωτέρω ὅντες οὐκ ἐκτοπίζουσιν ἀλλὰ κρύπτουσιν ἐαυτούς· ἔδη γὰρ ὡμμέναι πολλαὶ χελιδόνες εἰσὶν ἐν ἀγγείοις ἐψιλωμέναι πάμππαν, καὶ ἰκτῖνοι ἐκ τοιούτον ἐκπετόμενοι χωρίων, ὅταν φαίνωνται τὸ πρῶτον. The common Κite is merely a bird of passage in Greece, a very few remaining to winter there (kriper); the Black Κite is a rare visitor to the mainland of Greece. Both species are common, and breed, in Macedonia (riper, Εlwes, ἄc.). The statement Tκτῖνος φαίνεται appears in various Calendars, .f. Geminus, Isag. in Arat. Phaen. c. xVi, who dates its advent, according to Eudoxus thirteen days, to Euctemon eight, and to Callippus one day, before the vernal equinox. According to Grotius, Arat. Phaen. notae ad imagi. p. 55, Milvus,in Latin, refers to the constellation Cygnus; cf. Οv. F. iii. 793 Stella Lycaoniam vergit declivis ad Arcton Milvus. Haec illa nocte [vi. Κal. April.] videnda venit; see also Plin. xviii. 6; but according to Ideler, Sternnamen, p. 777, the dates given do not tally with tmis hypothesis, the heliacal rising of Cygnus being three months earlier; and he prefers to assume that the statements in the older Calendars referred to the bird of passage, and were mistakenly 1IΟΣ (rοπtiaaed). YISΟΣ- 1l attributed to a constellation by Οvid and Pliny. I am for myself inclined to think that Οvid did allude to the constellation, but that he did not mean (nor say) that on the date in question it rose πwih ts Jaa; as a matter of fact it then rose at midnight, and was on the meridian when it disappeared at sunrise. Tκτῖνος is also the name of one of the mystical λύκοι or ἄκμονες (q.v.) in Opp. Cyneg. iii. 331. 1Fth and eκοnd.- Hostile to κόραξ, Arist. H. A. ix. 1, 609, Ael. iv. 5, Phile, De An. 688, Cic. De Νat. Deor. ii. 49; friendly to πiφφιξ and ἄρπη, Arist. l. c., Ael. v. 48. Use θρύος as a remedy, Phile 725; place ῥάμνον in the nest as a charm, Ael.i. 55; how a stick from a Κiteʼs nest is a remedy for headache, Plin. xxix.(6) 36, xx. (a) 12; detest the pomegranate, ῥοία, so that they never even alight on that tree, and why, Dion. De Avib. i. 7. Suffer at certain seasons from sore feet, Dion. l.c. namely, at the time of the Solstice, Plin. x. (10) 12; and from sore eyes, Suid.s.v. ἴκτερος. See also Albert. M.De Animal.xxiii. 34, p. 641. Cf. supra, s. v. iέραζ. Hοw the Κites in Elis rob men in the market-place (cf. Ar. Av. 1624), but never molest the ἰερόθυτοι, Αel. ii. 47, Arist. De Mirab. 123, b.2 a, Theopomp. ap. Apollon. Hist. Mirab. x, Pausan. v. 14, Plin. l. c.; on the Κite as dangerous to sacrifices, cf. Ar. Pax 1099, Av. δ92; cf. τῷ ἰκτίνῳ τῷ ἐστιούχῳ, λr. Αv. δ6y. How the Κite was once a Κing, Ar. Av. 4999. The story in Plin. l.c., milvos artem gubernandi docuisse caudae flexibus, does not seem to occur in Greek. In Latin, Milvus is proverbial for its powers of fiight and of vision; cf. Pers. Sat. iv.26, ]uv. ix. 25, Martial ix. Εp. 55 Fab1e of ἰκτῖνος that lοst its vοice trying to neigh, Aes.Fab.ed.Halm, 70,Babr.73; Suid.; cf Iulian in Misopogone,p.366 (cit.Schneider in Αrist. .A. vi. 6) τὸν ἴκτινα ἐπιθέσθαι τά χρμετίζειν, ὦσπερ οἱ γενναῖοι τῶν ἵππων, εἶνα τοῦ μέν ἐπιλαθόμενον, τὸ δὲ μὴ δυνηθέντα ἐλεῖν ἰκανῶς,ἀμφοῖν στέ- ρεσθαι καὶ φαυλότερον τῶν ἄλλων ὁρνίθων εἶναι τὴν φωνήν: cf. ἄνθος. Fable οf λάρος καὶ ἰκτῖνος, Aes. 239. Proverb, προκυλινδεῖσθαι ἰκτίνοις, Ar. Av. ζoI; cf. Suid. ἔαρος γὰρ ἀρχομένου ἴκτινος φαίνεται. οἱ πένητες οὐν ἀπαλλαγέντες χειμῶνος ππροεκυλινδοῦντο καὶ προσεκύνουν αὐτούς. See also ρπη, 5aτυρρηγάλη, bίκτος, ἔλανος.
ινμʼΤ. Also ἰλάς, Athen. ii. 65 a, Eust. 947, 8. In some MSS. οf Athen. also τυλάς. Perhaps akin to rλα, i.e. κίχδα. A kind of hrush: for references, see κiχλη. Gesner, Belon, and others identify lλιάς as the Redwing, Iariar ihacas, L., on account ofits small sie (Arist.H.A.ix.20,617). In Αthen. ii. 65 a (c. 68) these words are omitted from a corresponding passage ; and the account of the nesting habits of κίχλη (Η. A. vi. 1) iΣ (cοπtiaed). Α GLΟSSARY οr REEE BIRDS are transferred to ἰλλάς. Both the Redwing and the Fieldfare are now winter-migrants in Greece, and not very common (kriper, Linder- mayer, ἄc.). The word was probably an old or dialectic form, meaning simply trash, to which it was sought to apply a specific meaning in Aristotle. κ

Λbte.- The epithet ξουθός is applied to various creatures, C.g. ἀηδὼν, ἀλκυών, χελιδών, μέλισσα,τέττιξ,all of which agree in being closely linked with religious symbolism. De Part.iv. 12, 695]. αὕτη ὅʼ ἐστὶ μικρῷ μέν μείζων σπίζης, ττὸ δʼ εἴδος ποικίλον, ἰδία δʼ ἔχει τά τε περὶ [τοὺς δακτύλους καὶ] τὴν γλῶτταν ὀμοίαν τοῖς ὅφεσιν· ἔχει γὰρ ἐπὶ μῆκος ἔκτασιν καὶ ἐπὶ τέτταρας δακτύλους, καὶ πάλιν συστέλλεται εἰς ἐαυτὴν. ἔτι δὲ περιστρέφει τὸν τράχηλον είς τοὺπίσω τοῦ λοιποῦ σώματος ἡρεμοῦντος, καθάπερ οἱ ὅφεις. ὅνυχας δʼ ἔχει μεγάλους μέν ὀμοίους μέντοι πεφυκότας τοῖς τῶν κολοιῶν· τῇ δὲ φωνή τρίζει (cf. Plin. xi. (47) 07). Αεl. H. A. ix. 13 lυγγας, ἐρωτικὰς ἄνθρωποί φασιν εἶναί τινες: cf. ibid. xV. 19. Mentioned among mimetic birds, Ael. H. A. vi. 19 ὑποκρίνεται ττὸν πλάγιον ἡ ἴυγξ αὐλόν. Superstition, interwoven with a phallic symbolism (cf. Dion. De Αvib. i. 23), used the lνγξ as a charm to bring back a strayed lover. Pind. P.iv. 214 (in connexion with ]ason and Medea) πότνια ὅʼ ὀξυτάτων βελέων ποικίλαν ἴυγγα τετράκναμον Οὐλυμπόθεν ἐν ἀλύτῳ ζεύξαισα κύκλῳ μαινάδʼ ὅρνιν Ευπρογένεια φέρεν πρῶτον ἀνθρώποισι. Theοcr. Id. ii lʼυγξ ἔλκε τὸ τῆνον ἐμὸν ποτὶ δῶμα τὸν ἄνδρα. Gk. Anth. (]ac. iv. 140, Anth. Pal. v. 209) υγξ ἡ Νικοῦς ἡ καὶ διαπόντιον ἔλκειν ἄνδρα καὶ ἐκ θαλάμων παῖδας ἐπισταμένη. Cf. Soph. Οenom. iii. 1 ἴνγγα θηρητηρίαν ἔρωτος. The bird was bound upon a wheel and spun round, cf. Theocr. ii. 30; Schol. Pindar, l. c. ap. Suid. ed. Gaisford λαμβάνουσαι γὰρ αὐτὸ δεσμεύουσιν ἐκ τροχοῦ τινος, δν ππεριρρομβοῦσιν ἄμα ἐςπάδουσαι. οἱ δέ φασιν ὅτι τὰ ἔντερα αὐτοῦ ἐξελκύσασαι καθάπτουσι τῷ τροχό. Cf Hesych., Suidas, Tetes in Lycophr. 310, Ael. H.A. i. 13, ἄc. In Pind. P. iv. 214 lυγγα τετράκναμον is supposed to be the bird thus bound, and cross-fixed or spread-eagled; cf. Pind.P.ii.40 τετράκναμον δεσμόν. See also ing, Ant. Οems, i. 381. In Χen. Mem. iii. 12, 17 ἔλκειν ἴυγγα ἐπί τινι is to work the bird against some one (Schn.), and perhaps the word is here used for the wheel itself or for a charm in a more general sense; cf. Aristaenet. ii. 18 τὸν φιλτροποιὸν ἰκέτευε ππάλιν κατʼ ἐκείνης ἀνακινῆσαι τὰς ἴυγγας: cf. also Pind. Νem. iv. 35 lγγι δʼ ἔλκομαι ἤτορ νεομηνίᾳ θιγέμεν: Luc. Dom. 13 ὦσπερ ἀπὸ ἴυγγος τῷ κάλλει ἐλκόμενος: Ar.Lys. 1110, Diog.L.vi. 2,76; irT (cοπtaaed). Α GLΟSSΑRY ΟF GREEE BIRDS Αel.xv. 19, Οpp. Hal. iv.132; still more loosely used in Ael. ii. 9, v.40, xii. 46, xiv. 15, ἄc. Compare also Virgils translation of Theocritus, Ducite ab urbe domum aea cανπaaa, ducite Daphnin. The magic wheel was properly called ῥόμβος, Τhεοcr. ii. 30, Οrphic. fr. xvii (Ηermann) ap. Clem. Alex. Strom. p. 15. δ, Luc. D. Meretr. iv. 5, c.; στρόφαλος, Schol. ad Synes. 361 D, Psell. in Schol. ad Οrac. Chald., τροχίσκος, Τ2eti.Chil.xi. 380 (trochiscilus, Apul.De Mag.xxx), cf. Clem. Αlex. Strom. v. δ, or ῥικός, Suid., and in Lat. aoaaas, Mart. ix. 30, Propert. iii.6, 26, aοta, Plaut.Cistell.ii. 1. 4, or tarro, Hor.Εpod.xvii.7. It was probably similar to, though not identical with, the ῥόπτρον, or tmbourine of the Corybantes, and the bird was, like that instrument, associated with the worship of Rhea, Dion. De Avib. i. 23. According to Marcells in Νonn. Dionys. ix. 116, the ῥόμβος was (and under the same name still is, in Italy) an instrument twirled round at the end of a thong, which means to say, I suppose, that it was a 'bull-roarer'; if this be so, the ἴυγξ τετράκναμος was not rotated round on its own axis, but spun at the end of a string, as we spin cockchafers. Concerning the magic wheel, see also Selden, De Diis Syr. i. 1 33. The bird is represented on a vase in connexion with Dionysus, Brit. . Mus. Vase Cat. Νo. 1293; and the Pindaric epithet ποικίλη has been interpreted as a link in its Dionysiac character (cf. R. Brown, un., Dionys. Myth, i. 339). In this connexion the name ύγγυῖ for Dionysus (Ηesych.), is very interesting. Another vase (No. 1356) represents Adοnis holding out the bird to Aphrodite. ἴνγξ was also used metaphorically for iε or desire, cf. Aesch. Pers. 959, Lyc. 310 and Schol. Heliodor. iv. 15, c. The ἴνγξ in Anth. Pal. v. 205 was engraved on an amethyst, 1ρύσο . ποικιλθεῖσα, διαυγέος ἐξ ἀμεθύστου γλυπτή: it is represented qn a gem, associated with ]ason and the Golden Fleece (Imh. Bl. and Κ. pl. xi. 21, p. 131) probably in illustration of Pind. Pyth. iv. Αccοrding to Νicander, ap. Anton. Lib. Met. 9, one of the nine Εmathidae, daughters of Pierus, was metamorphosed into the bird The ἴνγξ was equally sacred among the ancient Persians and Baby- 1onians, Marini Proclus, xviii, cf. Hopf, Thierorakel, p. 144. See also the remarkable description of the Royal ]udgement-seat at Babylon, Philostr. V.Apollon.i.25, where however the precise meaning of ἴυγξ is not clar: δικάζει μέν δὴ ὀ βασιλεὺς ἐνταῦθαʼ χρυσαὶ δέ ἴνγγες ἀποκρέμανται τοῦ ὁρόφου τέτταρες, τὴν Ἀδραστείαν αὐτῷ παρεγγυῶσαι, καὶ τὸ μὴ ὑπέρ τοὺς ἀνθρωπους αἶρεσθαι· ταύτας οἱ μάγοι αὐτοί φασιν ἄρμόττεσθαι, φοιτῶντες ἐς τὰ βασίλεια· καλοῦσι δὲ αὐτὰς θεῶν γλώσσας; d. Creuzer, Symb. ii. 22 1. See also Pseudo-Σoroastr, fr. 54, 6d. Cory. ἰr (cοπtiaaed). r- ΚκλafΔsoΣ Bury (]. οf Hellen. St. vii. pp. 157-160) supposes, chiefly from Theοcritus Id. ii, and Pindar Νem. iv, that the lυγξ was originally a saoοa-charν or invocation to the Moon-Goddess τώ, a theory supported by Mart. ix. 30, where roiθas is in like manner a aooa-chart, as also by such parallel passages as Virg. Ecl. viii. 69, and Tibull.i. 8. 21. The ἴυγξ was undoubtedly thus used in lnar rites, but the bird does not cry Τὡ, Τὼ, and the suggested derivation of its name and sanctity from such a cry cannot hold. It is interesting, however, to find that Io and ἴυγξ do come into relation with one another, the witch who by her spells had made Zeus enamoured of Io, being transformed by ]uno into the bird ἴυγξ, Νiceph.in Schol. ad Synesium, p.36o, Creuer,Symb. iii. 249; see also Schol. Pind. 1.c. I is thus quite possible that Τὼ and ἴυγξ are after all cognate, though the birdʼs cry had nothing to do with their etymology. ἴυγξ and ἴις come into relation with one another, as both connected with moon-worship; and the dialectic form of the latter, ἴβυξ (Hesych., ? ἴfυξ) suggests perhaps an ancient confusion between the two names.

In Aristotle, said to be a sea-bird, but not web-footed: mentioned as ὅρνις ποτάμιος, Aristoph. H. A. Εpit. i. 24, and θαλάσσιος, ib. i. 23. Αrist. H. A. ii. 17, 509 τὸν στόμαχον ἔχει εὐρὺν καὶ πλατὺν ὅλον. I. i. 12, 615 ὅρνις σχιζόπουςʼ ζῇ μέν περὶ θάλατταν, ὅταν δὲ καθῇ αὐτὸν εἰς τὸ βαθύ, μένει χρόνον οὐκ ἐλάττονα ἢ ὅσον πλέθρον διέλθοι τις· ἔστι δʼʼ ἔλαττον ἰέρακος. From this account and from its mention in ii. 17, between τὰ σχιζόποδα (ὡτίς] and τὰ στεγανόποδα (λάρος), Aubert and Wimmer identify καταρράκτης with Podicfs aaritas, the Eared Grebe, Mod. Gk. καραπαταίκιον (Erh. p. 48); Sundevall, on the other hand, with the Little Cormorant, Ahaiacrοcονα. οr Cναcνίν. pπαε. (vide κολοιός, ). Νeither of these birds, however, suggests by its habits the name καταρράκτης: and neither is white in colour, so that they at last conflict with the following excerpt from Dion.De Avib.ii.2 ὡς οἱ τῶν λάρων ἐλάσ- σονες, ἰσχυρὸς δὲ καὶ τὴν χρόαν λευκός, καὶ τοῖς τὰς φάσσας ἀναιροῦσιν ἰέραξι προσόμοιος . . . είς τὸν ππόντον οἶα πίπτων οἶσεται . . . τοὶς σκοπέλοις καὶ τοῖς αἰγιαλοῖς ἐφιζάνει. Further, a fabulous account of the breeding-habits. According to the same author (iii.22) σανίσιν εἰκόνας ἐπιγράψαντες ἰχθύων θηρῶσι τοὺς καταρράκταςʼ σὺν ὀρμῇ γὰρ ὡς ἐπί τινα καταπτάντες ἰχθὺν περιρρήγνυνται ταῖς σανίσι καὶ διαφθείρονται. These accounts are usually applied to the Gannet or Solan Goose, Sala assaaa (cf. Οedmann, Act. Αcad. Stockh. vii. 1786, Schneid. in Arist. vol. ii. p. S8); but the sie is incompatible with such an identification, and the bird is not a native οf Greece. The account in Plin. x. (44) 51 is wholly fabulous, and includes the story of the Birds of Diomede, οἱ καταράσσουσιν εἰς τὰς τῶν βαρβάρων κεφαλάς, Arist. Le Mirab. 9, δ36 a; cf. Ael. i. 1, and vide s.v. ἐρωδιός. Gesner, who is followed in modern ornithological nomenclature and by the lexicographers, identified καταρράκτης with the Skua, Aeslrir cαίαντπαάίεσ, L., a bird which does not occur in the Mediterranean.

A. ii. 17, 50 τῆς κοιλίας αὐτῆς τι ἔχει δμοιον προλόβῳ. (Cf. Gesner, p. 284 Dieses Vogels Magen ist dem Κropf gleich und gar nicht fleischigt). De Gen. iii. 75o μάλιστα δὲ ἢ κεγχρὶς πολύγονονʼ μόνον γὰρ σχεδὸν τοῦτο καὶ πίνει τῶν γαμψωνύχων, ἡ δʼ ὑγρότης καὶ σύμφυτος καὶ ἡ ἐπακτὸς σπερματι- κὸν μετὰ τῆς ὑπαρχούσης αὐτῇ θερμότητος. τίκτει δʼ οὐδʼ αὐτὴ πολλὰ λίαν ἀλλὰ τέτταρα τὸ πλεῖστον. Cf H. A. viii. 3, ‖94; Plin.x. (37) 52. Οn the other hand, according to Ael. ii. 43 ἐστὶ φῦλον ἰεράκων δ καλεῖται κέγχρηίς, καὶ ππότου δέεται οὐδέν. Mentioned also in Ar. Av. 30a, 589. 1181: Ael. xii. 4. Οne of the daughters of Pieros was transformed by the Muses into the bird κεγχρίς, Νicand. ap. Anton.Lib. c. 9. In Ael. xiii. 25, κεγχρίς seems to refer to a different bird, being mentioned as a dainty with συκαλίς, and κερχνής is mentioned in a similar way by Eubul. ap. Athen.ii.65 e.

HΑθΟT MSS. have κηλιός, καλιός, κολιός). The 6reen Wοodpecker, Paa. 2aνί, L. (a scarce bird in Greece, Lindermayer). Mod. Gk. πελεκάνος, τσικλιδάρα, δενδροφάγος, Heldr. Αrist. H.A. ii. 4, 50a : has feet like ἴαγξ. 1b. viii. 33, 593 τὸ μέγεθος ὅσον τρυγών, τὸ δὲ χρῶμα χλωρὸς ὅλος· ἔστι δὲ ξυλοκόπος σφόδρα, καὶ νέμεται ἐπὶ τὼν ξύλων τὰ πολλά, φωνῆν τε μεγάλην ἔχειʼ γίνεται δὲ μάλιστα περὶ Πελοπόννησον. Τhe preceding reference is as accurate as the following is unmeaning or mystical: Ib. ix. 1, 609, 610 φίλοι λαεδὸς καὶ κελεός· ὁ μέν γὰρ κελεὸς παρὰ ποταμὸν οἰκεῖ καὶ λόχμαςʼ πολέμιοι κελεὸς καὶ λιβυός. Suid. ὅρνεον ταχύτατον. Τhe identification of κελεός with Α GLΟsSΑRY oF GREEK BIRDS ΚAtΟΣ (cοπίνπεπ). the Green Woodpecker is said to have been first given by Gesner, cf. Schn. in Arist., vol. iii. p. 592. The bird κελεός figures, together with λαῖός and others, in a very mystical story of Boios, ap. Anton. Lib. c. xix. Celeus is also the name of a mystical king of Attica, in connexion with the story of Ceres and Triptolemus; this circumstance may be correlated with other Woodpecker-myths in Greek and Latin referred to s.v. bρυοκολάππτης: cf. Mythogr. Vatic. i. 7.8, iii.7. 2; Schol. ad Greg. Νaxianz. p. 48, ed. Gaisf., 8c. Οn other relations between Celeus and the Ceres-myth, c. Hom. Hymn. Cer. 475; Ar. Ach. 48; Pausan. i. 14, 35, 39, ii. 14; Anton. Lib.c. xix; vide also Creuzerʼs Symbolik (ed. 1836) i. 152, iv. 368, 384.
FfeΟΣ. MSS. have also κέμφος, κίπφος, γεῖφος. An unknown water- bird; usually, but without warrant, identified (after Schneider in Arist., and Promt. Lips. 1786, p. 501) with the Stormy Petrel Σahassirοaα palagiα, L. According to Hesych. identical wih κήξ. The accounts are fabulous, and the name is very probably foreign. Αrist. H. Ib. ix. 35, 620 ἀλίσκονται τῷ ἀφρῷ· κάπτουσι γὰρ αὐτόν, διὸ προσ- ραίνοντες θηρεύουσιν. ἔχει δὲ τὴν μέν ἄλλην σάρκα εὐὼδη, τὸ δὲ πυγαῖον μόνον θινὸς ὅζει. γίνονται δὲ πίονες. Cf Νic. Alexiph. 165-169 ἀφρὸν ἐπεγκεράσαιο θοοῦ δορπήῖα κέπφου, κ.τ.λ. See also Lyc. 76, Sy, and Tet. ad Lyc. 76 θαλάσσιον ὅρνεον λαροειδές, ὅπερ ἀμφῷ (sc. ἀφρῷ) θηρῶσιν οἱ παῖδες τῶν ἀλιέων. Cf. also Suidas, s.v. According to the Schol. in Ar. Pax 1067 εἰαι πολὺν μέν ἐν τοῖς πτεροῖς, ὀλίγον δὲ ἐν τοῖς κρέασι. Dion. De Avib. ii. 10 ἐκ τῆς κουφότητος οἱ ἀλιεῖς ὀνομάζουσινʼ τὸ γὰρ ὕδωρ ἄκρον τοῖς ποσὶν ἐπιτρέχει καὶ σημαίνει τοῖς ἄλιεῦσιν ἐπιτυχίαν. Feeds on small fish killed by tunnies and dolphins; sleeps seldom; afraid of thunder. Arat. Prognost. 916 καί πποτε καὶ κέπφοι ὀπότʼ εὔδιοι ποτέωνται ἀντία μελλόντων ἀνέμων εἰληδὰ φέρονται: cf. Schol.; see also Theophr. Fr.vi. 28; Symmach. (Schol.Ar.Pax 067) p. 217. See also Hesych.: εἶδος ὀρνέου κουφοτάτου περὶ τὴν θάλασσαν διατρίβοντος, ὃ εὐχερῶς ὑπὸ ἀνέμου μετάγεται· ἔνθεν λέγεται ὁξὺς καὶ κοῦφος ἄνθρωπος κέπφος (i.6. a δοοζχ); cf. Ar. Pax 1o67 κέπφοι τρήρωνες: Id. Plut. 912 ὦ κέπφε (Schol. καλεῖται δέ κοινῶς λάρος, a gall). Hence κεπφωθείς, Prov. vii. 22 (ed. Lλλ); cf. Cic. At. 13.40.
