κFYTοΣ, . κήρυλος, . κειρύλος (Ar. Av. 300), κήρυλλος (ustath. ad Hom.), a κίρυλον (Ηesych.). A doubtful, perhaps ioreign, word, sometimes appled to the Halcyon, sometimes compared with it. Sundevalʼs identification of κηρύλος with a second species which occurs in Greece, Aiedο (Ceayle) aadr, the Smyrna Κingfisher, is quite untenable, the poetical and mythical use of both κηρύλος and ἀλκυὼν being opposed to so concrete an interpretation. The suggested connexion with Lat. cοστaίεaς (Ο. Κeller, Lat. Etym., 1b93. p. 15) is in equal degree improbabl. Αlcman, 12 (2o) βάλε δή, βάλε κηρύλος εην, ὅς τ ἐὶ κύματος ἄνθος ἄμʼ ἀλκυόνεσσι ποτῆται νηλεές ἤτορ ἔχων ἄλιπόρφυρος εἶαρος ὅρνις. Cf. s.v. ἄλιππορφυρίς. Μosch. iii. 41 οὐδὲ τόσον γλαυκοῖς ἐνὶ κύμασι κηρύλος ἔδεν. Αrist. H.A. vwiii. 3, 93 b πeρὶ τὴν θάλατταν καὶ ἀλκυὼν καὶ κηρύλος. Ael. v. A8 ἀλκυόνα καὶ κήρυλον ποθοῦντας ἀλλήλων πάλαι ἴσμεν. Ib. vii. 17 κήρυλος καὶ ἀλκυὼν ὀμώνυμοι καὶ σὺμβιοι, καὶ γὴρᾳ γε παρειμένους αὐτοὺς ἐπιθέμεναι αἱ ἀλκυόνες περιάγουσιν ἐπὶ τῶν καλουμένων μεσοπτερυγίων. Cf. Antig. H. Mirab. 23 (27), where κηρύλος is said to be the male kingfisher; cf. also Hesych. κηρύλοςʼ ἄρσην δρνις συνουσιαστικός, τινές δὲ ἀλκυόνα: also Τ2etνes ad Lyc. 387; Schol. Ar. Av., Schol. Theocr.vii. 57; Eustath. ad Hom. 1l. i. 558. In Clearch. ap. Athen. . 332 E, numbered among τοὺς ὅρνιθας τοὺς ππαρευδιαστὰς καλουμένους, with τρόχιλος and ὁ τῇ κρέκι προσεμφερὴς ἐρωδιός. Mentioned also by Archilochus, fr. 121 ap. Ael. xii. 9 κίγκλος-κινεῖ δὲ καὶ τὰ οὐραῖα πτερά, ὡσπεροῦν ὁ παρὰ τῷ Ἀρχιλόχῳ κήρυλος. In Ar. Av. 299, usually written κείρυλος, as if from κείρω. Cf. infra s.V. σπποργίλος. The names and attributes of κηρύλος are undoubtedly akin to those of κεῖρις οr Ciris; and it is interesting to note that, according to Hesy- chius, the name κεῖρις applies either to a hawk or to the Halcyon. I would place the legend of ἀλκυὼν and κηρύλος side by side with the astronomic parable of Haliaetus and Ciris. Vide s.vv.Δλιάετος, κipι9. t- 1rtΟΣ κY. (See also s. vV. αόα, κήδ.) A sea-bird. Babr. cxv. 2 λάροις τε ταὶ κήῦξιν εἶπεν ἀγρώσταις. Αpollod. 28, ad Lucian. i. 178; said by Schol. to be the male ἀλκυὼν, and identical with κηρύλος. 1n Dion. De Avib.ii.7, applied rather to the female ἀλκυὼν· εἰ τὸν ἄρρενα τελευτῆσαι συμβαίη, βoρᾶς ἀπεχόμεναι καὶ ποτοῦ παντὸς ἐπὶ ππολὺ θρηνοῦσι καὶ διαφθείρονται, καὶ τὰς φδὰς δʼ εἰ καταπαύειν μέλλοιεν, κήῦξ κήῦξ συνεχῶς ἐπειποῦσαι σιγῶσιν. Kήύκος δὲ φωνῆς μήτʼ ἐγώ, μήτʼ ἄλλος ἀκούσαι τιςʼ φροντίδας γὰρ καὶ τελευτὰς σημαίνει καὶ δυστυχήματα. Suidas, s.v. Τμερινὰ ζῷα (whatever that may mean) mentions κήῦκες as sea- birds, together with ἀλκυόνες and ἀηδόνες. Οn the fable of Ceyx, Αlcyone, ἄc. see Οvid. Met. xi. 269, ἄc. ἄc.; Ceyx comes into relation with Hercules and the Argonautic lgends in Anton. Lib. c.xxvi; and the Hesiodic myth of Ceyx and Cycnus is of the same order. We may, I think, rest assured that κῆῦξ was not originally a concrete and specific bird-name, but a mystical term associated with tne Halcyon-myth (cf. s. v. κηρύλος).

Ib. ix. 12, 61 5 περὶ τὴν θάλατταν βιοῖ. τὸ ἦθος πανοῦργος καὶ δυσθήρατος, ὅταν δὲ ληφθῇ, τιθασσό- τατος. τυγχάνει δʼ δν καὶ ἀνάππηροςʼ ἀκρατὴς [cf. De Gen. ii. 99] γὰρ τῶν ὅπισθέν ἐστιν. Αel. xii. 9 πτηνόν ἐστι ἀσθενές τὰ κατόπιν, καὶ διὰ τοῦτό φασι μὴ ἰδίᾳ μηδέ καθʼ ἐαυτὸν δυνάμενον αὐτὸν νεοττιὰν συμπλέξαι, ἐν ταῖς ἄλλων δὲ τίκτειν· ἔνθεν τοι καὶ τοὺς ππτωχοὺς κίγκλους ἐκάλουν αἱ τῶν ἀγροίκων παροιμίαι (cf. Menand.'Τhais 4,ap.Suid.and Phot.(.132, Meineke)κίγκλου πτωχότερος). κινεῖ δέ ττὰ οὐραῖα πτερά. Cf. Aristoph.in Antiar. (2.9551ap.Ael.l.c.ὀσφὺν δʼ ἐξ ἄκρων, διακίγκλισον ἡύτε κίγκλου. Autocr. in Tympan. (2. δ91) ap. Αel.l. c. οἶα παίζουσι παρθένοι ... οἶα κίγκλος ἄλλεται. Cf. also Theogn. 1257 κίγκλος πολυπλάγκτος: also verb κιγκλίζω, Τhεοgn. 03, προσκιγ- κλίζομαι, Theocr. v. 117; also κιγκλοβάταν ῥυθμόν Aristoph. fr. 6 (2. 997) ap. Ael. l.c. Vide Hesych. κίγκλος, ὅρνεον πυκνῶς τὴν οὐρὰν κινοῦν· ἀφʼ οὗ καὶ τὸ κιγκλίζειν, ὅ ἐστι διασείεσθαι· τινές δὲ σ[ε]ισοπυγίδα. Sundevall takes κίγκλος to be a Sandpiper, Iiaga sp. chiefly, as it seems, because σχοινίλος is doubtless a name for the Wagtail,Aotaclla. But I prefer to believe that κίγκλος is also a Wagtail, firstly because the movement is much more characteristic and noticeable in that bird than in the Sandpiper, secondly because of the statement as to its sie, and Α GLΟS8ΑRY Οr qREER BIRDS ifKΟΣ (οatίaaad). thirdly because of its asserted tameness in captivity. The statement in Aelian, about the nest (also ap. Phile, 492), may perhaps be explained by the fact that, according to Κriper, the Wagtails in Greece all 1eave the plains in summer to breed, resorting to the hills, or in the case of A. aaelaaocghala to the salt-marshes and lagoons. At the same time it is evident that allsions to κίγκλος, ἄC. are much influ- enced by notions and superstitions connected with the bird lγζ.

Gk. κιρκινέζ is said to be a name for the Κestrel (Heldr.), vide s.v. sei5i. In Homer, the bird of Apollo, δεξιὸς ὅρνις, Ἀπόλλωνος ταχὺς ἄγγελος, Od. xV. 525 ; an emblem of swiftness, ἐλαφρότατος πετεηνῶν, I. xii. 1399, Οd. 2iii. 87; cf. Apoll. Rh.i. 10a9 ἡύτε κίρκουν ὡκυπέτας ἀγεληδὸν ἀποτρέσσωσι πέλειαι: ib. iii. 5431 561, iv.486; hostile to ψάρ,κολοιός,and other small birds, ll.xvii.757. Frequent in Aesch. usually, as in Homer, an enemy of the Dove; Suppl. 223 ἐσμὸς ὡς πελειάδων ἴζεσθε, κίρκων τῶν ὀμοπτέρων φόβῳ, Pr. V. Sy7 κίρκοι πελειῶν οὐ μακρὰν λελειμμένοι (note in this passage the association with Egyptian παφος); mentioned in connexion with the Tereus-myth, as metamor- phosing with ἔποψ, fr. 32, ap. Arist. H.A. ix. 49 b ἔποψ .. . δς ἦρι μέν φαίνοντι διαπάλλει πτερόν κίρκου λεπάργου : ὑs a portent, pursuing an eagl, πρόὶ ἐαχάραν οίβου, Pers. 205; cf. Suppl. 60 ὅπα τᾶς Τηρείας μήτιδος οἰκτρᾶς ἀλόχου, κιρκηλάτου τʼ ἀηδόνος. Αrist. H.A. ix. 36, 620 τρίττος τῶν ὶεράκων ‖ῷ κράτει]; ib.ix. 1.609 b ἀλὼπεκι πολέμιος, cf. Ael. v. 48, Phile, 20a, Wotton, De Diff. Anim. vii. 143, ἅc. In Plin. x. 8 crcοs occurs as an alternative reading for αέίΔha.; cf. crcs as the name of a gcm, similis accipitri, Plin. xxxvii. 10. Mentioned as hostile to the Dove also in Ael. iii.46, v.50 αἱ δὲ περι- στεραὶ πρὸς αἐτῶν μέν κλαγγὴν καὶ γυπῶν θαρροῦσι, κίρκων δὲ καὶ ἀλιαέτων οὐκέτι: to τρυγὼν and to κορώνη, ib. vi. 45 ; to κίρκη, ib. iv. ‖, ‖8; and to mice, Batrach. 499. How it places chicory (πικρίς) in its nest as a charm, Ael. i. 35, Phile, 7722, or wild lettuce, ἔγρια θριδακίνη, Οeopon. Α GLΟsSARY οr oEEΕ B1DS ΚiPKΟΣ (cοπaaεσ). xv. 1. 19, with which it salves is eyes, Anatol. p. 297 (cf. iέραξ); and is killed by pomegranate-seed (όοιᾶς σίδην κοπεῖσαν), Ael.vi. 46, Phile,637. Used by fowlers, pp. Cyn. i. 64 αὐτοῖς ἐππὶ δρυμὰ συνέμπορος ἔσπετο κίρκος. The bird is not identifiable as a separate species, and is so recog- nized by Scaliger and others. Neither the brief note as to its sie in a corrupt passage of the ninth book of the History of Animals, nor the mystical references to its alleged hostilities and attributes in Αristotle, Aelian, and Phile, are sufficient to prove that the name indicated at any time a certain particular species. The word is poetical, and is chiefly used in relation to πέλεια, or with reference to Apollo. The attempts on the part of commentators to assign κίρκος to a particular species are all based on the epithet λέπαργος. Thus Sundevall suggests the Hen Harrier or Ringtail, Carcas ayaaeas, of which the male is blueish-grey: while Belon and others of the older naturalists, followed by Camus, assigned the name to the Moor Buzard or Marsh Harrier, C. aκνaρίaosas, which is only white beneath the tail. But the meaning of λέπαργος is in reality unknown; it will not bear using, nor is it likely to have been used, as a specific or diagnostic epithet. Cf. s.v. ππύγαργος. The chief allusions to κίρκος are obviously mystical, though the underling symbolism, involving also the symbolic meanings of the Hoopoe, the Dove, the Crow, the Fox, the Pomegranate, c. is not decipherable. In this connexion, the passage in Οpp. Cyn. iii. 293-339 is important and suggestive, but I refrain from putting forward a tenta- tive hypothesis as to its meaning; we have here enumerated five kinds of λύκοι, of which the first is τοξευτήρ or ξουθός, the next three are κίρκος, χρύσεος, ἰκτῖνος, 3nd the last θηρεύει ἐπὶ πτώκεσσιν ὀροiων, i.e. is λαγωφόνος (the last two are called ἄκμονες, Q.V.); of these five names the last four are all also names or epithets of hawks.

Thras. 1 (3, 42o Mein.) λαλιστέραν οὐ κίτταν, οὔτ ἀηδόνʼ οὔτε τρυγόνα; Lyc. 1319 τὴν λάληθρον κίσσαν: and imitative faculty, Ael. vi. 19, Plu De Sol. Anim. p. 973 C, Dion. Οvid, Meu. v. 294, 663; Mart. Εp. xiv. 76; Pers. Prol.; Plin.x. 33- Sundevall supposes the Magpie (which is very much rarer in Greece than the ]ay) to have been meant, but the description tallies much better with the ]ay, which still retains the name. The Magpie is now called καρακάξα (Heldr.). In Ialian, gaasa, chέτα, σεαεα, ;ica, ἀς. apply both t the Magpie and to the ]ay, as very possibly κίσσα also did in Greek. Pliny (. 29) gives an accurate account of the Magpie, describing it as a variety of ;ica of recent advent to the neighbourhood οf Εome.

I. ix. 49 B. 632 b μεταβάλλει δὲ καὶ ἡ κίχλη τὸ χρῶμα· τοῦ μέν γὰρ χειμῶνος ψαρά, τοῦ δὲ θέρους ποικίλα τὰ περὶ τὸν αὐχένα ἴσχειʼ τὴν μέντοι φωνὴν οὐδέν μετα- βάλλει. Cf. Ael. xii. 28. This would suggest a confusion of species: the more variegated birds being Fieldfares and Redwings; the latter are said to occur in large flocks in Spring (v.d. Mihle), though all alike have departed by Summer. Its song alluded to, Ar. Ach. 1116 πότερον ἀκρίδες ἔδιόν ἐστιν, ἦ κίχλαι; Ar. Pax 531, ἅc. C. νεοττοὺς δὲ κόκκυγος λέγουσιν ὡς - οὐδεὶς ἑώρακεν· ὁ δὲ τίκτει μέν, ἀλλʼ οὐ ποιησάμενος νεοττιάν. ἀλλʼ ἐνίοτε μέν ἐν τῇ τῶν ἐλαττόνων ὁρνίθων ἐντίκτει καταφαγὼν τὰ ἐὰ τὰ ἐκείνων, μάλιστα δʼ ἐν ταῖς τῶν φαβῶν νεοττιαῖς . . . τίκτει δʼ ὁλιγάκις μέν δύο, τὰ δὲ πλεῖστα ἔν. ἐντίκτει δὲ καὶ τῇ τῆς ὑπολαῖδος νεοττιᾷ· ἡ δʼ ἐκπέττει καὶ ἐκτρέφει. Id. H. A. ix. 29, 618 a τίκτει μάλιστα μέν ἐν ταῖς τῶν φαβῶν καὶ ἐν ὑπολαῖδος καὶ κορύδου χαμαί, ἐπὶ δένδρου δʼ ἐν τῇ τῆς χλωρίδος καλου- μένης νεοττιᾷ. τίκτει ἔν φόν. ὅταν αὐξάνηται ὁ τοῦ κόκκυγος νεοττός, ἐκβάλλει τὰ αὐτῆς [ τρέφουσα] καὶ ἀπόλλυνται οὔτως. οἱ δὲ λέγουσιν ὡς καὶ ἀποκτείνασα ἡ τρέφουσα δίδωσι καταφαγεῖν· διὰ γὰρ τὸ καλὸν εἶναι τὸν τοῦ κόκκυγος νεοττὸν ἀποδοκιμάζειν τὰ αὐτῆς. I. ix. 49 E, 633 μεταβάλλει τὸ χρῶμα καὶ τῇ φωνῇ [οὺ] σαφηνίζει, ὅταν μέλλῃ ἀφανίζεσθαι· ἀφανίζεται δʼ ὑπὸ κύνα, φανερὸς δὲ γίνεται ἀπὸ τοῦ ἔαρος ἀρξάμενος μέχρι κυνὸς ἐπιτολῆς. Cf. Ael. iii. 3o ὀρᾶται ὁ κόκκυξ ρος ὑπαρχομένου εἰς ἀνατολὰς Σειρίου: Dion. De Avib. i. 13 ππρῶτος τῶν λοιπῶν ππτηνῶν ἡμῖν τὸ ἔαρ ἀγγέλλων. 1etamoxhosis with the Hawk, Arist. Οther 1vths and Dlgends.- How ]upiter, in the shape of a Cuckoo, sought Hera on Mount Thornax; and how for this reason the cuckoo figures on Heraʼs sceptre, Pausan. ii. 17, 4: cf. Schol. ad Theocr. xv. 64; hence the mountain was called ὅρος Kοκκύγιον, Pausan. ii. 36, 1; cf. Creuzer, Symb. iii. 248; cf. also the Teutonic θaaansόeν, rimm, D. Mytm. p. 646, ἄc. From its propinquity to Sparta, and from the circumstance of the Cuckoo having come in a cloud, Creuzer (l.c.) conjectures an allusion to the same story in Ar. Av. δ14; cf. also the weather prophecy in Hesiod, 1 c. How the Cuckoo was king over Egypt and Phoenicia, Ar. Av. 50a. In these latter statements we have evidence of a confusion with the ΚΟKY (εοπtaaaed). κ0Y -- i0aΟfΣ Hοopoe, vide s.vv. ἔπποψ, κοικούφα; for the relations betwween the Cuckoo and the Hoopoe, Der Κuckuk und sein Κister, v. oaτνfΣ, ;.κέλυμβος (Ar.Ach.), κολυμβάς (Athen. 355 c, Anton.Lib.). A water-bird; especially a Grebe. ΚΟΑYi8l (cονtiaaed). ΟλΟtΣ-Ο8a Αr. Av. 304, Ach. S75, brought to market from Boeotia. Mynd. in Athen. ix. 395 d ἡ μικρὰ κολυμβὶς πάντων ἐλαχίστη τῶν ἐνύδρων, ῥυπαρομέλαινα τὴν χροιὰν καὶ τὸ ῥύγχος ὀξὺ ἔχει, σκέπτον τε (lect. dub.) τὰ δμματα,τὰ δὲ πολλὰ.καταδύεται. The above passage from Alex. Mynd., so far as it is intelligible, is a good description of the Little Grebe or Dabchick, Poaaceys aaiaor, L. which is a common resident in Greece (Mod. Gk. βουτηκτάρα). In Αrist. De Part. iv. 12 we find a minute account of the Grebeʼs foot, but without 3 name. Αccording to Νicand. ap. Anton. Lib. c. ix, one of the Emathides, daughters of Pierus, was metamorphosed into the bird κολυμβάς.

ΚΟPa The legend of Coronis (Paus.ii 26, 6), mother of Aesculapius: the raven sent for water by Apollo, and punished for dallying by the way; hence the raven, alone of birds, does not bring water to its young : Dion. De Avib. i. 9, Phil. De An. Pr. vi: c. Callim. fr. nuper edit. Gompert, Mitth. a.d. Εainersammlung, 1893, κenyon, Class. Rev. 1893, p. 430. See further, Ael. i. 47; also Οvid, F. ii. 249, where Cωνππ. in the same stoy appears as a constellation; according to Hyginus, Poet. Astron. C. xl, the raven waited to devour some ripening fgs, and the punishment of everlsting thirst is correlated with the juxtaposition of the constellations Corvus and Crater, which latter the Hydra guards (Οvid, F. ii. 243 Continuata loco tria sidera Corvus et Αnguis, Et medius Crater inter utrumque iacet). Hence Prov. κόραξ ὑδρεύει, Hesych., Suid. Hygin. Fab. 202, Gower, Conf. Amant. iii, c. Οn the name Coronis in connexion with Moon-symbolism, cf. Bl., and Κell., p.32, pl. 24 (he constellation Corvus set shortly after Cancer, with which latter the Ass is associated). A. i. 13, 615 b ἦ χλωρίς ἐστιν ἡλίκον κόρυδος: ix. 49 B, 633 b ἐπίγειος, κονιστικός (i.e. bathes in the sand, like a hen): viii. 16, 60o a φωλεῖ: vi. 1, ‖59 τίκτει ἐν τῇ γ, like the quail and the partridge: ix. S,614 a ἐπὶ δένδρου οὐ καθίζει ἀλλʼἐνὶ τῆς γῆς: ix.29, 618 a the cuckoo lays in its nest, which is placed on the ground, cf. Ael. iii. 30. Is caught with bird-lime, Dion. De Avib. iii. 2, or by help of the owl, ib. iii. 17. The crest referred to proverbially, Simon. fr. 68 (Plut.ii. 91 Ε, Soq A, V. Timol. xxxvii, 253 E) πάσαισιν κορυδαλλίσιν 1ρὴ λόφον ἐγγίνεσθαι. Arist. mentions neither the singing nor the soaring οf the lark; but Theocr. vii. 141 has ἄειδον κόρυδοι καὶ ἀκανθίδες, and x. 50 ἐγειρομένῳ κορυδαλλῷ, Aaarale cονγάαίο. The larkʼs song was apparently not appreciated: cf. Alciphr. Εpist.48 δν ἐγὼ τῆς ἀχαρίστου φωνῆς ἔνεκα ὀρθῶς κορυδὸν [σ. ὀρθοκόρυδον] καλεῖσθαι πρὸς ἡμῶν ἔκρινα: Epigr. εὶ κύκνῳ δύναται κορυδὸς παραπλήσιον δειν: and proverbs cited by Schneider in Arist. vol. iv.p. 128. Vrieties. - Arist. H. A. ix. 25, 617 b δύο γένη, ἡ μέν ἐτέρα ἐπίγειος καὶ λόφον ἔχουσα, ἡ δʼ ἐτέρα ἀγελαία καὶ οὐ σπορὰς ὥσπερ ἐκείνη, τὸ μέντοι χρῶμα 6μοιον τῇ ἐτέρᾳ ἔχουσα, τὸ δὲ μέγεθος ἔλαττονʼ καὶ λόφον οὐκ ἔχει, ἐσθίεται δέ. The first species is the Crested Lark, Aiaada crisata, La, a permanent resident in Greece; the other is the Common Lark, Aίαaάα ανυενsίς, L., a winter migrant (v.d. Muhle, p. 36, Lindermayer, p. 49). Both species receive the name κορυδαλός in Mοd.Gk. (Erhard). Myth and Σlςοnd. - Arist. H. A. ix. 1, 610 φίλοι σχοινίων καὶ κόρυδος καὶ λίβυος καὶ κελεός. i. 1, 609 b ὁ πέλλος πολεμεῖ κορύδῳ, τὰ γὰρ φὰ αὐτοῦ κλέπτει. I0. 6o9 πολέμια ποικιλίδες καὶ κορυδῶνες καὶ πίπρα καὶ χλωρεύς. Hοstile also to ἀκανθυλλίς, Phile, 683, Ael. iv. 5. Uses the grass ἄγρωστις as an amulet or protection, Ael. i. 35, as does the Hoopoe, Phile, 724; whence the proverb ἐν κορυδοῦ κοίτῃ σκολιὴ κέκρυπται ἄγρωστις, Geopon. xV. 1, 19. Uses, in like manner, oak-leaves, Phile, 725. Is killed by mustard-seed, νάπυος σπέρματι, Phile, 662, Ael. vi. 46; cf. Galen, Theriac. i. 9, 943, 40. Diosc. ii. ‖9, 79. How the lark led an Attic colony to Corone in Messenia, and how Apollo, under the name Kόρυδος, had a temple and cured diseases there, Paus. iv. 34, δ. How the Lemnians honoured the larks, τὰ τῶν ἀττελάβων εὐρίσκοντας cὰ καὶ κόπτοντας, Plut. ii. 38o F. The story of the Lark and his Father, Aesop ap. Ar. Av. 471 κορυδὸν πάντων ππρωτην δρνιθα γενέσθαι, προτέραν τῆς γῆς, κᾶππειτα νόσῳ τὸν πατέρʼ αὐτῆς ἀποθνήσκεινʼ γῆν δʼ οὐκ εἶναι, τὸν δὲ προκεῖσθαι ππεμπταῖον· τὴν δʼ ἀπο- ροῦσαν ὑπʼ ἀμηχανίας τὸν πατέρʼ αὐτῆς ἐν τῇ κεφαλῇ κατορύξαι. The same lgend may account for Atheneʼs supposed enmity to the Crow, cf. Οvid, Amor. ii. 6, 35 cornix invisa Minervae. Uses ἀριστερῶν as a charm, Ael. i. 35; also ῥάμνον, Phile, De Am.Pr. 725; and περιστερεῶνα τὸν ὕπτιον, eopon. xV. 1, 19. Α weather-prophet: of storm, Theophr. Sign. vi. 3, 39 ἐὰν ταχὺ δις κρώζῃ καὶ τρίτον χειμέρια σημαίνει . . . καὶ ὁψὲ ἔδουσα: Arat. 10o2 καὶ ἤσυχα ποικίλλουσα [.κωτίλλουσα,Lοb.] ρῃ ἐν ἐσπερίῃ κρωγμὸν πολύφωνα κορώνη: ib. 1022 καὶ ἐννεάνειρα κορώνη νύκτερον ἀείδουσα: cf. Arist. fr. 241, 1522 b, ap. Ael. vii. 7, Pluu ii. 674 B, Virg. G. i. 388, Hor. C. iii. 17, 13, Lucan v. 556; a sign of fair weather, Theophr. vi. 4, 3 καὶ κορώνη ἔωθεν εὐθὺς ἐὰν κράξῃ τρίς, εὐδίαν σημαίνει, καὶ ἐσπέρας χειμῶνος ἡσυχαίαν ἔδουσα: cf. Ael. 1c., Virg. G. i. 410, Geopon. i. 2, 6, c. Α bad summer is portended when the fig-leaves are shaped like a crows foot, Plut. ii. 410 Ε. The Crow in auguny, seldom mentioned in Greek, save in Ar. Aves; see also Ael. iii. 9, where a solitary crow is mentioned as an evil omen; according to Porph. De Abst. iii. 4, the Arabs understood the language οf crows. A crow on the left-hand is unlcky, Virg. Εcl. i. 15, Cic. De Div. i. 39, Plaut. Asin. ii. 1, 12, 8c.; cf. Hopf, Οrakelhiere, p. 115. Cf.also Horap. i. 8 ττὸν Ἀρεα καὶ τῆν ʼἈφροδίτην γράφοντες,δύο κορώνας ζωγραφοῦσιν, ὡς ἄνδρα καὶ γυναῖκα,ἐπεὶ τοῦτο τὸ ζον δύο cὰ γεννᾷ, ἀφʼ δν ὄρρεν καὶ θῆλυ γεννᾶσθαι δεῖ. ἐπειδὰν δὲ γεννήσῃ, ὅπερ σπανίως γίνεται, δύο ἀρσενικά, ἢ δύο θηλυκά, τὰ ἀρσενικὰ τὰς θηλείας γαμήσαντα οὐ μίσγεται ἐτέρᾳ κορώνῃ, οὐδὲ μὴν ἡ θήλεια ἐτέρᾳ κορώνῃ μέχρι θανάτου, ἀλλὰ μόνα τὰ ἀποζυγέντα διατελεῖ. διὸ καὶ μιᾳ κορώνῃ συναν- τήσαντες οἰωνίζονται οἱ ἄνθρωποι, ὡς χηρεύοντι συνηντηκότες ζφῳʼ τῆς δὲ τοιαύτης αὐτῶν ὀμονοίας χάριν μέχρι νῦν οἱ λληνες ἐν τοῖς γάμοις· ἐκκορί, κορί, κορώνη· λέγουσιν ἀγνοοῦντες. Modern naturalists accept the story of the singing swans, asserting that though the Common Swan cannot sing, yet the Whooper or Whistling Swan does so. It is certain that the Whooper sings, for many ornithologists state the fact, but I do not think it can sing very well; at the very best, ἀaat Aonitaat aaaci 5er slaga iogaαάα αχρπi. For my part, I imagine I discern a stellar attribute in the one bird, and a lnar in the other. By this word, and its Semitic root, I would seek to explain the curious canting heraldry' which represents the constellation of the Pleiads as a bunch of grapes, and gives to it the name jότρυς (θότρυν γὰρ αὐτὰς λέγουσιν, Schol. 11. xviii. A86; Ideler, Sternnamen, p. 317). Οn coins of Mallos in Cilicia, we have Doves represented, whose bodies are formed by bunches of grapes, and in other cases the dove is lost and replaced simply by the grapes: on the relation of these fgures and their other associated symbols to the constellation of the Pleiad, see M. ]. I imagine that an old confusion, intentinal or unintentional, between oἰνάς and οἶνος may have been the cause of this strange and unwonted prefigurement of the constellation. Gk.: it does not occur in Aristophanes, save in the Homeric parody in Ar. Av. 575. In Hom. frequent; the only Homeric word for pigeon, save for the occurrence of φάσσα in the compound φασσοφόνος, I. xV. 238. Smyrn.xii. 12 ἴρηξ σεύε πέλειαν· ἐπειγομένη δʼ ἄρα κείνη, χηραμὸν ἐς πέτρης κατεδύσατο: cf. also Virg. Aen. v. 213. In Aristotle distinguished from ππeριστερά: . A. v. 13, ‖44 b ἔτερόν ἐστι περιστερὰ καὶ πελειάς· ἐλάττων μέν οὐν ἢ ππελειάς, τιθασσὸν δέ γίνεται μᾶλλον ἡ περιστερά. ἡ δὲ ππελειὰς καὶ μέλαν καὶ μικρὸν καὶ ἐρυθρόπουν καὶ τραχύπουν, διὸ καὶ οὐθεῖς τρέφει. [The contrary stated, Athen.i. 3994 C.] Ib. viii. 12, ‖97 b ἀπαίρουσι δὲ καὶ αἱ φάτται καὶ αἱ πελειάδες, καὶ οὐ χειμά- ζουσι, αἱ δὲ περιστεραὶ καταμένουσιν. According to Sundevall, πέλεια is here in Aristotle the Stock-dove, C. οεπασ, οἱνάς being the Rock-pigeon, C. ἄυπα, φάψ οr φάττα, the Ring-dove, C. ;alaaaas, and ππeριστερά, the Domestic Pigeon. Aubert and Wimmer, on the other hand, take οἰνάς as the Stock-dove, and leave πέλεια in doubt. For my part, I do not think the Stock-dove was recognied as a distinct species, but was included, as in Mod. Gk. (Erhard, Heldreich), under the name φάσσα with the Ring-dove. Excluding the Turtle-doves, there then only remain the wild Rock-pigeon (Mod. Gk. ἀγριοπεριστέρι) and the domestic variety; and I imagine that both oἰνάς (q.v.) and πέλεια refer, in Aristotle, to the wild Rock-pigeon, and περιστερά especially to the Tame Pigeon; cf. also Moeris (p. 405, ed. och, 183o) εἰωtάς, ἡ κατοικίδιος περιστερά, γὰρ ἀγρία, πελειάς. The account in Arist. H. A. V. 13 is corrupt and not to be too much depended on, especially in view of the discrepant quotation in Athenaeus. The chief difficulty in the whole interpretation is the passage H. A. viii. 12, where it is asserted that both φάτται and πελειάδες migrate and do not remain fSξl (aοataaed). fhἔia over the winter, whereas all the Pigeons occur more or less in Greece in winter-time, and it is in summer that the Ring-dove and Stock- dove, which breed elsewhere, are seldom found. The passage can hardly have been written in Attica; it would appear more consonant with the truth did we suppose it written, for instance, in Macedonia. Εxcept in the doubtul case of Aristotle, πέλεια is in no sense a specific term: we have seen it applied in Homer to the Rock-pigeon, and on the other hand the πέλειαι in the Oak-woods of Dodona must have been either Ring-doves or Stock-doves (vide infra). In Οpp. Cyn. i. 351, where pigeon-fanciers are said to cause the pigeons by a display of ' purple stuff to bring forth young of a like colour, πεληῖάς and also τρήρων are used of tame pigeons. Varro, De k.R.iii.7 nihil est timidius columba; Οvid, A. Amat. i. 117, ii. 363, ἄc. c. Is swiftness: Soph. Οed. Col. 1081 ἀελλαία τταχυρρωστὸς πελειάς, cf. also Philoct.289, 1146; Eur. Bacch. 1090 πελείας ὡκύτητʼ οὐχ ἤσσονες. The Dove pursued by the Hawk or Eagle, a type of swiftness and of timidity : 11. XXi. 493, Xii. 139, Q. Smyrn. xii. 12; Aesch. Pr. V. 3g8 κίρκοι πελειῶν οὐ μακρὰν λελειμμένοι ἤξουσι; Eurip.Andr. 114o οἱ δʼ δπως πελειάδες ἰέρακʼ ἰδοῦσαι πρὸς φυγὴν ἐνώτισαν: Οvid, Met.i. 07 sic aquilam penna fugiunt trepidante columbae; cf. ibid.v.605, Trist.i. 1,75; Virg. -Εcl. i. 11; Lucret. iii.751; Phaedr. Fab. i. 311 3, 4c. Thus Medea comes to ]ason, as a Dove seeking shelter from the Hawk, Val. Flacc. λrgon.viii. 32. The Dοve in the cltches of the Eagle or Hawk, as an omen, Οd.x. 243, 2V. 525, Sil. 1al. Pun. iv. 104; cf. Virg.Aen. 2i. 721. Hera and Athena, coming to the aid of the Argives, compared to Dοves: I. v. 778 αἱ δὲ βάτην, τρήρωσι πελειάσιν ἴθμαθʼ ὀμοῖαι. For various interpretations of this simile, see the Scholia, also Ameis and other commentators; but the allusion is probably neither to swiftness nor to dainty tread, but to the ancient and widespread prefigurement οf the deity as a dove (cf. int. al., F. L. W. Schwartxe, Urspr. d. Mythologie, p. 218); in the Homeric Delian Hymn, v. 114, Iris and Eileithyia βὰν δέ ποσὶ τρήρωσι πελειάσιν ἴθμαθʼ ὀμοῖαι, with which cf. Ar. Rh. ii. 328, ii. 557, ἀc. and Schol. οἰωνῷ δὴ πρόσθε πελειάδι πειρήσασθε νηὸς ἀποπρὸ μεθέντες ἐφίεμενʼ . . . ἄκρα δʼ ἔκοψαν οὐραῖα πτερὰ ταίγε πελειάδος· ἢ δʼ ἀπόρουσεν ἀσκηθῆς: see also Apollod. i. 9, 22, Hygin. Fab.xix, Propert. ii. 26, 39 cum rudis Args Dux erat ignoto missa columba mari, dc.; cf. the account of the Πλαγκταὶ πέτραι οr Cyanean rocks, Οd. xii. 62 τῇ μέν τʼ οὐδὲ οτητὰ παρέρχεται, οὐδὲ πέλειαι τρήρωνες, ταί τ ἀμβροσίην Διὶ πατρὶ φέρουσιν: cf Plut. ii. 156 F. The Dove in the story of the Argonauts again, in connexion with the fire-breathing bulls, Apoll. Rh. iii. 541 τρήρων μέν φεύγουσα βίην κίρκοιο ππελειάς, ‖ ὑψόθεν Aίσονιδέω πεφοβημένη ἔμπεσε κόλπποις. In the above legends there are numerous traces of the mythical astronomy of the Pleiads. This view is a very ancient one; cf. Athen. 1i. 490 Ε πρώτη δὲ Mοιρὼ ἠ Bυζαντία καλῶς ἐδέξατο τὸν νοῦν τῶν Ὀμήρου ποιημάτων, ἐν τῇ Mνημοσύνῃ ἐπιγραφομένῃ φάσκουσα τὴν ἀμβροσίαν τῷ Διὶ τὰς Πλειάδας κομίζειν. Κράτης δὲ ὁ κριτικὸς σφετερισάμενος αὐτῆς τὴν δόξαν, ὡς ἴδιον ἐκφέρει τὸν λόγον. Athen. l.C. from Pindar, Simonides, Simmias, Lamprocles, ἄc. where the πλειάδες are called πελαιάδες: .g. Lampr. (p. ‖54 Bergl) aτε ποταναῖς ὀμωνυμοὶ πελειάσιν αἰθέρι κεῖσθε. The Pleiads are also supposed to be alluded to in Alcman, fr. 23 (Bergk) ταὶ πελειάδες γὰρ ἀμίν Ὀρθίᾳ φᾶρος φεροί- σαις νύκτα διʼ ἀμβροσίαν ἄτε σείριον ἐστρον ἀνειρομέναι μάχονται. The coincidences on which rests the foundation for an astronomical interpretation of the above myths are chiefly the following. As has been mentioned above, s.v. ἀλκuών, the sun rose together with the Pleiads in the sign of the Bull, at the vernal equinox, the ancient opening of the year. 1f the Cretan ]upiter was a Su-god, he might be said to be nursed by the π[ε]λειάδες: the sign Taurus may have been the Cretan Bull; and a transit through that sign may have been the celestial Bόσπορος οf the Argonautic voyage. The Dove as an attribute of Venus is similarly explained, the ioννas Peaerr being in the sign Taurus, the sign of the Pleiad. The Doves of Νestorʼs cup, Il. xvi. 634, are also supposed to have reference to the Pleiades, Athen. xi. 49a92. Οn the Dove of Deucalion: cf. Plut. Mor.968, 1185. Paean. 58 (30); Diod. i. 13, iii. 71; 3il. 11al. iii.678; Serv. in Aen. iii. 466, Εcl. ix. 13. According to Strabo, ap. Eustath. in Οd. p. 1760, and Geogr. vii. fr. 1a the priestesses were called πελειομάντεις, Cf. κορακομάν- τεις. According to Philostr. Imagf. i. 33 (387 k), a choir of priestesses danced round an oak, on which sat a golden dove. Dion. Halic.Ant. Rοm. i. 141 4I compares with the Dodonaean dove the πῖκος or δρυοκολάπτης οf the oracle of Mars. The whole story is intricate and confused. It seems clear that the priestesses were called πέλειαι (cf. Paley, Aesch. Suppl. ed. 2, p. xiv) or πελειομάντεις; and also that the oracle was not essentially an auguy or bird-oracle, but one in which tree-worship, river-worship (cf. Macrob. v. 18), and thunder- worship (cf. Mommsen, Gr. ]ahres. p. 432, ἄc.) were alike involved. The doves of Dodona link on to the story of Deucalion, to the doves Α GLΟSSΑRY ΟF GREER BIRDS fξRἔi (cοatiaεά). that fed the infant Σeus, to the dove in other Zeus-myths (cf. Athen. ix. 995 a, Ael. V. 1. i. 15) and to the doves of Dione. 1f we seek to get further back, we enter the mist of Pleiad-symbolism. I has been suggested by Landseer, Sabaean Eesearches, p. 186, from the study of an Assyrian symbolic monument, that the stars which Conon converted into the Coma Berenices (Ηygin. P. A. ii. 24, cf. 1deler, Sternnamen, p. 295) and which lie in Leo opposite to the Pleiades in Taurus, were originally constellated as a Dove; and that this constellation, whose first stars rise with the latest of those of Argo, and whose last rise simultaneously with the hand of the Hus- bandman, links better than the Pleiad into the astronomical Deluge- myth. The case rests on very little evidence, and indeed is an ilustration of the conficting difficulties of such hypotheses: but it is deserving of investigation were it only for the reason that the Coma Berenices contains seven visible stars (Hiygin.), and the Pleiad six, a faint hint at a possible explanation of the lost Pleiad. ππελειοῦρέμμυν, an epithet of Salamis (according to the Schol. and Hesych., but see Paley and other commentators), Aesch. Pers. 309; cf. πολυτρήρων (s.v. τρήρων); also the Asala Coaaaaria, Plin. iii.(6) 12. Prοvexb.-ἡμένη πελειάς, a ʼpigeon,' a simpleton: Εustath. Plin. x. 47 (66) faucibus ipsis inest alterius uteri genus. That the Pelican can render up its food from its apouch' was much commented on by the ancients: hence the Hebr. name ξααίλ, 1t. 'to vomit.' But the Pelican feeds on fish, not (?) on shell-fish: and moreover A. crispas is common in Greece and is not limited to the north. Hence various writers have doubted the common interpretation, e.g. Gesner, Brandt (Descr. Animal. Rusti- corum, 1836, p. 53), Van der Hoeven (Handb. d. λool.. ii. p. 396) and especially Aubert and Wimmer (op. cit. i. p. 104), who suppose a species of Heron to be meant. But the passage in Dionysius (s.v. ππελεκῖνος) is only applicable to the Pelican, and the latter is distin- guished from ἐρωδιός im Ael. v. 35, Phile, c. ix, ἂc.; the Heron and the Pelican seem however to be confounded by Plutarch, l. c. De Gen. ii. 746 b, iii.740 b, Ael. iv. 1, vii. 19, ἅc. c. διὸ καὶ τὰ cὰ τῆς θηλείας συντρίβει ἴνα ἀπολαύῃ τῶν ἀφροδισίων: Arist.ap. Αthen.l.c., Ael.iii.5. (Wih this and similar fables, cf.]erem.xvii. 11). μάχονται δὲ οἱ χῆροι αὐτῶν πρὸς ἀλλήλους καὶ ὁ ἡττηθεὶς ὀχεύεται ὑπὸ τοῦ νικήσαντος, Athen. l. c., Plin. l. C. ὀχεύουσι δὲ καὶ οἱ τιθασοὶ τοὺς ἀγρίους· γίνεται δὲ τοῦτο κατά τινα ὦραν τοῦ ἔτους, Alex. Mynd. ap. Athen. l. C. τοὺς νεοττοὺς ὀχεύουσι, H. A.v. 5, 541; cf. De Gen. iii. i, 751, Ael. xvii. 15, Antig. H. Mirab. 8 (87), Athen. 1c.. Plin.1 c. 4c. Bastards, ἐκ πέρδικος καὶ ἀλεκτρυόνος, De Gen. ii. 738 b. Athen. ix. 390 b. An evil omen: Σάμιοι πλείσαντες εἰς Σύβαριν καὶ κατασχόντες τὴν Σιρῖτιν χώραν, ππερδίκων ἀναπτάντων καὶ ποιησάντων ψόφον, ἐκπλαγέντες ἔφυγον, καὶ ἐμβάντες εἰς τὰς ναῦς ἀνέπλευσαν, Ieges. ap. Athen. xiv. 656 c. Α fabled metamorphosis of Perdix, son of Daedalus, Hygin.Fab.274, Οvid, Met.viii. 236-260. This subject is discussed in a curious essay by Οerlnd, Ueber die Perdixsage, Halle a. S., 1871. The writer identifies Perdix with the Lapwing. Sacred to Zeus and Latona, Ael. x. 35- δύο ἔχουσι καρδίας,Τhεοphr.ap.λthen.l c. Ael x.35 (in Paphlagonia; cf. Plin. xi 0). Hostile to χελώνη, Ael. iv. , and to ἐχῖνος ὀ ποταμογείτων, Phile, 678. Friendly to ἔλαφος (hence a stags head used as a decoy), Dion. De Αvib. i. 11; to φάττα, Ael. v. 48. Use κάλαμος as a remedy, Ael. i. 35, Phile, 723, Ceopon. xV.1; also ὀρίγανον, Aeὶ.v. 46, or a leaf of laurel, Plin.viii. 27, or the herb variously known as perdicium, helxine, sideritis or parthenium, Plin. xxi. (16) 62; xxii. (7) 19. Proverbial expressions. πέρδικος σκέλος, πέρδικος υἴός, ἄc.vide supra. Αrchil.95, ap. Athen. i. 388 f. πτὼσσουσαν ὥστε πέρδικα: with which cf. Αr. A. i. 1, 488; τὸ σῶμα ὀγκῶδες, De Gen. iii. 1, 749 b; καρποφαγεῖ καὶ ποηφαγεῖ, H.A.viii. 3, ‖93. οὐκ ἀνακύππτει πίνουσα, H. A. ix.7, 613. Blinks with both eyelids, De Part. Αn. ii. 12, 657, Plin. xi. (37) 57. καὶ κονίονται καὶ λοῦνται, Arist. H. A. ix. 49 B, 633 b; does not migrate, 1b. viii. 3, 931 597 b. Lives to eight years old (when blinded as a decoy) Ib. ix. 7, 613, Plin. x. (35) 52. Is the prey of hawks, φασὶ τὰς περιστερὰς γινώσκειν ἔκαοτον τῶν γενῶν [τῶν ἰράκων], Arist. H.A. ix. 36, 620, Ael. v. 50, ἄc.,ἄc. 11s coo, ]. Poll.v. 13 εἴποις ἂν περιστερὰς γογγύζειν. Ther.86o and Schol.; and on the white seeds of Aeioscφiaa, Plin. xxvi. (8) 42. Captured by nets (ἐπισπάστροις) or more easily by springes (βρόχοις), Dion. De Avib.iii. 12. λnatoxmical particulars.- Arist. H. A. ii. 15, ζo6 μικρὸν ἔχει τὸν σπλῆνα, ὥστε λανθάνειν ὀλίγου τὴν αἴσθησιν. Ib. 506 b τὴν χόλην ἔχει πρὸς τοῖς ἐντέροις, cf. Plin.xi. 37 (.). Said to lack gall, Horap. i. 57; see also Clem. Alex., Paedag. i. 15, Isidor. Οrig. xii. 7, 61, and many mediaeval naturalists and poets, 6.g. Walther v.d. Vogelw. xix. 13 r6s ane dorn, ein t6be sunder gallen; cf. Hamlet, ii. 2. Galen, De Atra Bile 9, states correctly that the Pigeon possesses gall and merely lacks τὴν ἐπὶ τῷ ἤπατι κύστιν. Arist. H. A. ii. 17, 508 b πρόλοβον ἔχει πρὸ τῆς κοιλίας : cf. Plin.xi. 37 (79). θερμὴν τὴν κοιλίαν, De Gen.iii.7, 670. Her wings are covered with silver, and her feathers with yellow gold: Arist. De Color. 3, 793 (6, 79, 96) οἱ τῶν περιστερῶν τράχηλοι φαίνονται χρυσοειδεῖς τοῦ φωτὸς ἀνακλωμένου. Bacch. i. 1, 17 appears in the sense of lover, and Iarar, Bacch. i. 1, 35 in that of mistress. Varieties.- Aristotle enumerates the following names or varieties of pigeon : H. A. viii. , 593 φdψ [om. Aa, Ca], φάττα [οm. Da], περιστερά, οἰνάς, τρυγών: ib. viii. 12, 5997 b φάτται, πελειάδες, τρυγόνες, περιστεραί: ib. v. 131 44 b περιστερά, πελειάς, φάττα, οἰνάς, τρυγών. Αrist. ap. Athen. ix. 393 f περιστερά, οἰνάς, φάψ, φάσσα, ττρυγών. Callim. περὶ ὀρνέων, ap. Athen. ix. 394 6, Ael. V. H. i. 15 φάσσα, πυραλλίς, περιστερά, τρυγών : for all which names, see under their proper headings. ππεριστερά is usually the generic word: περιστερῶν μέν εἶαι ἐν γένος εἴδη δέ πέντε, Αrist.fr. 271, 1527, ἄc. When used specifically, it refers to the Domestic Pigeon, Colaaaa iavia, vvar. aοννeslica: Arist. H. A. i. 1, Iδ8 b τὰ μὲν ἄγροικα ὦσππερ φάττα .. .τὰ δὲ συνανθρωπίζει οἶον ππεριστερά; ib. v. 131 ‖44 b τιθασσὸν δὲ γίνεται μᾶλλον ἡ περιστερά: cf. Soph.fr.745 (ap. Plut. Mor. 959 6) περιατερὰν ἐφέστιον οἰκέτιν τε: Plat. Theaet. 199 b λαβεῖν φάσσαν ἀντὶ περιστερᾶς, a wild pigeon for a tame one. Cf. εὶωῦάς, ἡ κατοικίδιος περιστερά, ἡ γὰρ ἀγρία, πελειάς, Mοeris (p. 40χ, ed. Κοch, 1830); with which cf. Themist. Οr. xxii. p. 273 C οὐ γὰρ δὴ τῶν περιστερῶν μὲν αἱ ἐθάδες πολλάκις τινὰς καὶ ξενὰς ἐπάγονται. In its generic use it appears, .f. in the statement that in cities περιστεραί are tame, in country districts very wild, Ael. iii. 15 περιστεραὶ δὲ ἐν ταῖς πόλεσι τοῖς ἀνθρώποις συναγελάζονται, καί εἰσι πρᾳόταται καὶ εἰλοῦνται παρὰ τοῖς πόσιν, ἄc. The passage in Ar. Lys. 754 appcars to refer to the extreme familiarity of the city-pigeons. White pigeons: first seen in Greece near Athos, during the Persian War, Charon ap. Athen. ix, 394 d, Ael. V. 1. i. 15; though whie fIYESA (cοataaεσ). fssτssa pigeons were not honoured in Persia, being deemed hostile to the Sun, Herod. i. 138; the white doves had probably been the property of Phoenician, Cilician, or Cypriote sailors (Hehn). Οn white pigeons, cf. also Alexid. 3, 4δ1, ap. Athen. l.c. λευκὸς Ἀφροδίτης εἰμὶ γὰρ περι- στερός: see also Varro, De R. Ε. iii. 7, Οvid, F. i. 452, Ep. xV. 7, Met. ii. 537, xiii. 674, x. 15, Martial, ἄc. The whie pigeons were apparently the sacred race of Babylon, which after- wards spread t Syria and to Europe: cf. Hehn, Culturpfi. p. 279, Engl. ed. p. 258; they are still numerous in Damascus (cf. Thomson, Land and Book, p. 271). Galen distinguishes between the κατοικίδιοι and the ἄγριαι, βοσκάδες, or νομάδες, De Comp. Medic.ii. 10 (iii. p.5141 ed.Κih), cf. De Simpl. Med.Τemp. x 25 (ii. p. 302); for the latter, dove-cotes were built in the fields near Pergamus. Varro, De R. R. iii. 7 gives a similar account : agrestes maxime sequuntur turres, in quas ex agro evolant, suapte sponte, et remeant. Alterum genus illud columbarum est clementius, quod cibo domestico contentum intra limina ianuae solet pasci. Hoc genus maxime est colore albo. There is also a mixed breed, genus miscellum, reared in the περιστεροτροφεῖον: cf. Οvid, Heroid. xV. 37 et variis albae iunguntur saepe columbae. See also on the care of domesticated and half-domesticated pigeons, Colum. De R. .viii. 8, Pallad. i. 24, Οeopon. xX. Σοmins or Carrier-φigeοns. Pherecr. fr., ap. Athen. ix. 305 b ἀπό- πεμψον ἀγγέλλοντα τὸν περιστερόν. For references to dove-cotes, see also Οvid, Met. iv. 48 albis in turribus; id.Τr.i. 4.7 aspicis, ut veniant ad candida tecta columbae, Accipiat nullas sordida turris aves; Mart.xiii. 31 quaeque gerit similes candida turris aves. Αccοrding to Varro, a pair of fuull-grown pigeons was worth from 200-10o sesterces; and L. Axius had purchased a pair of a dealer for 500 denarii. The Sacred Doves of Venus or Astarte. Pigeons were sacred in the eyes of the Syrians, like the fishes of the river Chalos, Χen. Εxp. Cyr. i. 419; they were kept in great numbers at Ascalon, Ctes. ap. Diodor. ii. 4, Philo ap. Εuseb. Prep. Evang. viii. 14, 64 (cf. the Dove on coins of Ascalon, Εckhel, Doctr.Νumm.iii.p.a45); and at Hierapolis, Lucian, De Syr. Dea, c. 14, where the statue of Atargatis had a gold dove on her head, Lucian, ibid. c.33. Οn Venusʼ doves, see also Virg. Aen. vi. 100, Οvid, Met. Xiv. 597, Fulent. Mythol. ii, ἄc. 8ς. Οn the doves in Palestine, cf. Tibull. i.7, 17 Quid referam, ut volitet crebras intacta per urbes Alba Palaestino sancta columba Syro ? cf. Hygin. Fab. 197, Lucian, De Syr. p. 912, Ioseph.1c. cit. Clem. Alex. πρδς λλην ii, Philo ap. Euseb. P. Ε. viii. c. 14, 1. 398, ἄc. See also the account given above of the introduction of white pigeons into Greece, and compare the sanctity of the bird in modern times at Mecca, Constantinople, Venice, Moscow, ἄc. Οn the cult of Doves in Syria, cf. Broeckhuis, ad Tibull. l.c. Τhe cult of the goddess, carried from Ascalon to Cyprus (Herod. i. 105, Pausan. i. 14, 7), brought thither the sacred doves; cf. Antiphon. ap. Athen. xiv. 635 B ἡ Rύπρος δʼ ἔχει πελείας διαφόρους: the white Paphian doves, Martial, viii. 28, 13, cf. Νemes. fr. De Aucup. 22; see also Eustath. Hom. Il. p. 1035. In this paper various resemblances are shown to exist between classical superstitions and Chinese popular notions, an important subject concerning which too little information is accessible. Among other points, the writer states that in Chinese legend the Dove is often confused with the Cuckoo, that the former as well as the latter bird is said to metamorphose into the Hawk, and that the Dove is said to lay in the Magpieʼs nest: these facts may have some bearing on the obscure Aristotelian statements referred to above (s.v. aόκκιζ) concerning the nesting of the Cuckoo in the nest of φάψ. ffTeS. The account given of the sie of the bird and the descriptions in Αthenaeus and Aelian agree perfectly with the Scops Οwl; this is a noisy bird, repeating its cry with monotonous persistence. But it appears to spend the summer only in S. Εurope, migrating to Africa in winter. The passage in Aristotle is perhaps faulty in this con- nexion, owing to misinterpretation of the name ἀείσκωψ as though from ἀεί. Sundevall supposes the other variety to be the Short-eared Owl, Scri. ὄναcλyοίas, a somewhat larger species, which appears merely to pass through Greece on its migrations: vide infra, s.v. dτός. Αccording to Dupuis (Οrig. de tous les cultes, ii. p. 260, 8vo, lan iii), the Stymphalian birds are the constellations of Aquila, Cygnus and Vultur or Lyra, which rise together with, that is to say are garaaaeἄlοas of, tme sign Sagittarius (cf. Hygin., Columella, ἄc.). Starting from the Lion (with which te labours of Hercules began) the sign of the Archer is the fifth in order: it was moreover the domicile of Diana, to whom belonged the temple at Stymphalus. A similar explanation possibly underlies the story of the Birds of Diomede. 2rΡοYΟΣ-1XΟ1iΟΣ Ττʼ. A bird-name, mentioned, in connexion with a fabled meta- morphosis, by Boios ap. Anton. Lib. c. xxi. Cf Plin. x. (29) 44, Geopon. xv. 1, 22, Festus. Αlex. Mynd. ap. Athen. ii. 65 b ἄτερος τῶν αἰγιθάλων ὑφʼ δν μέν ἔλαιον καλεῖται, ὑπὸ δέ τινων πυρρίας· συκαλὶς δʼ, ὅταν ἀκμάζῃ τὰ σῦκα. Athen. ibid. δύο δʼ εἶναι γένη αὐτοῦ, συκαλίδα καὶ μελαγκόρυφον. ἀλίσκονται δʼ αὐται τῷ τῶν σύκων καιρῷ. Mentioned also, Ael. xiii. 25. Αubert and Wimmer suppose the Marsh Tir, Paras paiasaris, L., P. αἰiciβillas, Gmel., to be meant. Sundevall supposes a confusion between that bird (μελαγκόρυφος) and the Black-headed or Pied Flycatcher, Aascicapa aἰricφilla, L., (συκαλίς), as accounting for the imaginary metamorphosis. But the Black-headed Flycatcher is probably chosen incorrectly, and should be the Black-cap Warbler or true Aeccαβαο, Sylvia aricφilla. I is the latter and not the former bird which comes down into the plains in autumn and is caught in multitudes on the fig-trees (kruper, p. 241, ἄε.). The former is a comparatively scarce bird in Greece (riper, Lindermayer). Coray, on the other hand, identifies συκαλίς with the Golden Οriole, in Mod. Gk. συκοφάγος. The Plamingo, Ahoeaiσρίνa. αalgaατa, L. Αr. Av. 271 Ἐf. οὔτος οὐ τῶν ἡθάδων τῶνδʼ δν ὀρᾶθʼ ὑμεῖς ἀεί, ἀλλὰ λιμναῖος. ΠΕ. βαβαί, καλός γε καὶ φοινικιοῦς. Π. εἰκότως· καὶ γὰρ δνομʼ αὐτῷ γʼ ἐστὶ φοινικόπτερος. This is the only reference to the bird in classical Greek, and the identification here is at best doubtful. The succeeding reference to the Cock might lad one to suspect that under the name Phoenicopterus some bird less unlike the Cock than the Flamingo is, was here alluded to: such a bird, for example, as Poshyrio hyaciathiaas, the Purple Water-hen (vide s.v. ππρφυρίων]. The question, however, is not capable of settlement. The Flamingo occurs in Greece only as a rare straggler, though abundant on the opposite coast of Asia Minor (Von der Mihle, p. 118; Lindermayer, p. 155, ἄc.). Cf. Gesner, H. Anim. 1ib. iii Mirum est huius tam pul- chrae et eximiae avis nomen ab Aristoteli taceri, cum Aristophanes, qui viit eadem aetate, meminerit; sed Graecis etiam raram esse hanc avem puto. Flamingos were seen, however, by Bory de St. Vincent, in the marshes of Οsman Aga near Νavarino. Heliodorus, Aethiop.vi. 3 describes the bird as Νeιλῷον φοινικόπτερον: and the Scholiast ad ]uv. xi. 139 states in like manner, abundans est in Africa: it, apparently, is also mentioned as a dainty, by Philostr. Vit. Apoll. Tyan. viii. p. 387 (ed. Paris, 1605) as ὅρνις φoινίκεος. In Crat. Νem. fr.4, ap.Athen.ix.373 d ὅρνις φoιικόπτερος, is probably the Cock. It has been stated above, s.v.γλωττίς, that Belon (Ηist.des Oyseaux, viii. 8) identified that bird with the Flamingo; so also did Aldrovandi (Οrnithol. iii.20,4), with as little reason. To the opinion there ascribed to Linnaeus, the following words of Gesner should have been sub- joined: ego vero iis quas Gallinulas aquaticas nostri vocant avibus Glottidem adnumero, quae omnes fissipedes sunt; cf. also Scaliger (in loc.Aristot.) Glottis autem quae sit nondum mihi constat; ridiculum quod quidam de Phoenicoptero ausus est pronuntiare. In Latin, references to the Flamingo are frequent and free from doubt. Cf. ]uv. xi. 139 et Scythiae volucres et phoenicopterus ingens; Martial, Ep. iii. 58, 14 nomenque debet quae rubentibus pennis; τb. xiii.71 dat mihi penna rubens nomen; Suet. Cal. 22, ἄc., ἄς. ' That the Tongue of this Volatile was much commended, and in i2 Α GLΟSSARY Οr GREEK BIRDS 4ΟftΟfΤE5ΟI (cοatiaed). great Esteem, for its excelent Taste and most delicious Relish, will appear from the following Quotations (Douglass, op. infra cit.) : Plin. x. (4δ) 68 Phoenicopteri linguam praecipui saporis esse, Apicius docuit; Martial, xiii.71 sed lingua gulosis Νostra sapit: quid si garrula lingua foret? cf. also Sueton. Vitell. xiii. The brain was also a tid-bit, and Heliogabalus (Lamprid. 20, p. 108) exhibuit Palatinis dapes extis et cerebellis Phoenicopterorum refertas. Receipts for the cookery of Flamingos are given (without mention of the tongue) by Apic.(?) De Re Coquin. vi. 7. I am inclined to believe that such costly indulgences of the palate were often determined by obscure superstitious motives (as are many Chinese lxuries) rather than by real or imaginary refinements of taste. Νevertheless the Flamingoʼs tongue is said to be still appreciated: cf. Von der Mihle, Οrnithol. Fr. 50, 4- Herod. ii.73 ἔστι δὲ καῖ ἄλλος ὅρνις ἰρός, τῷ οὔνομα φοῖνιξ· ἐγὼ μέν μιν οὐκ εἶδον, εἶ μὴ ὅσον γραφῇ· καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ σπάνιος ἐπιφοιτᾷ σφι, διὰ ἐτέων (ὡς Τλιουπολῖται λέγουσι] πεντακοσίων. φοιτᾶν δὲ τότε φασί, ἐπεάν οἱ ἀποθάνῃ ὁ πατήρ. ἔστι δέ, εἶ τῇ γραφῇ παρόμοιος, τοσόσδε καὶ τοιόσδε· τὰ μέν αὐτοῦ χρυσόκομα τῶν πτερῶν, τὰ δὲ ἐρυθρά· ἐς τὰ μάλιστα αἰετῷ περιή- γησιν ὀμοιότατος, καὶ τὸ μέγαθος. τοῦτον δὲ λέγουσι μηχανᾶσθαι τάδε, ἐμοὶ μέν οὐ πιστὰ λέγοντες. ἐξ Ἀραβίης ὀρμεώμενον ἐς τὸ ρὸν τοῦ Τλίου κομίζειν τὸν ππατέρα ἐν σμήρνῃ ἐμπλάσσοντα, καὶ θάπτειν ἐν τοῦ λίου τῷ ἐρ. κομίζειν δὲ οὕτω· ππρῶτον, τῆς σμύρνης cὸν πλάσσειν ὅσον τε δυνατός ἐστι φέρεινʼ μετὰ δὲ ππειρᾶσθαι αὐτὸ φορέοντα· ἐπεὰν δὲ ἀποπειρηθῇ, οὗτω δὴ κοιλήναντα τὸ φόν, τὸν πατέρα ἐς αὐτὸ ἐντιθέναι, σμύρνῃ δὲ ἄλλῃ ἐμπλάσ- σειν τοῦτο κατʼ ὅ τι τοῦ cοῦ ἐκκοιλήνας ἐνέθηκε τὸν ππατέραʼ ἐσκειμένου δὲ τοῦ ππατρὸς γίνεσθαι τὼυτὸ βάροςʼ ἐμπλάσαντα δὲ κομίζειν μιν ἐπʼ Alγύπτου ἐς τοῦ Τλίου τὸ ἰρόν. A new Phoenix-period is said to have commenced A.D. 139, in the reign of Antoninus Pius; and a recru- descence of astronomical symbolism associated therewith is manifested on the coins of that Emperor. Various remedies were to be obtained from its nest, Plin. xxix. 9 (Trridere est vitae remedia post millesimum annum reditura monstrare). For frther references, oriental and classical, see Bochart, Hieroz. ii. coll. 88, S49. Οn the Phoenix as an astronomical symbol of a cyclic period, see (int. al.) Marsham, Canon. For representations of tme Phoenix, see jomardʼs Descr. de lΕg. Antiq. i. c. 5. The Phoenix has been taken by Cuvier, Len, and others, for the Golden Pheasant,-a coarse materialising of a mythic symbol (Hehn). On the study and interpretation of such sacred enigmas of the ancients, see Groteʼs Hist. i. c. 16. The subiect deserves to be studied under many heads; for example, the varying terms assigned to the Phoenix-period, and the various astronomical cycles thereby indicated; the relation of the Phoenix to the Palm-tree (Eg. δενaavφοῖνιξ τὸ ὅρνεον, δενπε ὴ φοῖνιξ τὸ δένδρον, Lauth, Situngsber. Bayer. Akad. 1876, p. 94) in connexion with the whole symbolic imagery of the latter; the relation of the Phoenix to the Heron (Lauth, l c.; cf. supra s.v. 5aιήῦ), involving also the depicting οf the Soul as the Phoenix and the question of the term assigned to the Soul's wanderings. In the Rhodian Swallow-song already referred to, two very curious features are the alternate balance or 'parallelism' of successive lines and the apparent influence of accent on rhythm: the text has been much emended by commentators, in order to obtain a more accurate scansion than the song ever, perhaps, possessed. It is easy to 8ufiest yet other emendations: for instance in ll. 17, 18 ἂν δὴ φέρῃs ττι, μέγʼ ἄν τι δῆ φέροιο seems better than the common reading μέγα δή τι. In the association together of the Swallow and the Νightingale, a curious feature is the similarity of the poetical epithets applied to both. The epithet Πανδιονίς, and the inclsion of Pandion in the myth, whatever they may exactly mean, seem to me to have something to do with the festival of the Iανδία, which took place at Athens μετὰ τὰ Διονύσια (Photius); that is to say, at or near the Vernal Equinox, and not far from the time when the χελιδόνισμα is still sung. The statement of Photius that Iανδία is a name for the Moon, is also of great interest, Α GLΟSSΑRY ΟF GREEK BIRDS XHhllf8 (cοπtiaed). especially in connexion with the Swallowʼs relation towards the un- doubtedly solar ἔποψ. Buffon and others have supposed from the name ὡτίς that the Houbara (which is very rare in Greece) is chiefly meant: but the etymology is doubtful; the 'ears are not mentioned save by Oppian, Cyneg. ii. 47 ὡτίδες, αἴσι τέθηλεν ἀεὶ λασιώτατον οὗας: and besides the cheek-tufts of the Common Bustard might suggest εαrs as well as the crest of the Houbara. It is however the Houbara, as the common Αfrican species, which is alluded to in Plutarch ap. Athen.l.c. o, ;. ὠτός. Α Horned Οwl, especially the Short-eared Οwl, Sσπr δraahyolas or Asi αccφντνν.. Further (loc.dub., A.and W.) ἐ δʼ ὡτὸς ὅμοιος ταῖς γλαυξὶ καὶ περὶ τὰ ὡτα πτερύγια ἔχωνʼ ἔνιοι δʼ αὐτὸν νυκτικόρακα καλοῦσιν (cf Hesych.). ἔστι δὲ κόβαλος καὶ μιμητὴς, καὶ ἀντορχοὺμενος ἀλίσκεται, περιελθόντος θατέρου τῶν θηρευτῶν, καθάπερ ἡ γλαύξ. A less absurd version, ibid. 91 a; cf. Plut. Mοr. ii. 961 Ε. Hence ὡτός, οne easily taken in, a 'gull. Plin.x.(23) 33 Οtus bubone minor est, noctuis maior, auribus plumeis eminentibus, unde et nomen illi; quidam Latine asionem vocant: imitatrix avis ac parasita, et quodam genere saltatrix, ἄc. Casaubon and others,followed by Lidd.and Sc.,state that Athenaeus confounds δτος with ὡτίς. There is indeed a confusion in the text, due to the interpolation in 36o d μιμητικὸν δέ ἐστι, κ.λ. between two state- ments referring to ὡτίς; but the respective statements as to ὄτος and ὡτίς are correct. The Short-eared Owl is indicated in the following statements : (1) as a migratory bird; (2) as associated with the quails, i.e. a bird οf the open country; (3) as being diurnal and not nocturnal. The commentators have often fallen into error from ignorance of the habits οf the Short-eared Οwl: e.g. Gesner, i galliis, a οti, 'nocturnam avem aut noctuae similem nullam migrare arbitror. (Certain other species are, at least, partially migratoy; cf. (at. al.) Giglioli, Avif. 1ml., 1886, 1p. 227, 228, ἐc. In Arist. H. A. viii. 12, and in Plin. l.c. there appears to be some confusion with the Long-eared or Common Horned Οwl, Slri. οίas, L. Ἀντοʼ. It is perhaps desirable that I should point out that I have several times in this book, quite with my eyes open, quoted authors whom scholars now look upon with distrust or even altogether reject. The student who is not ashamed to consult Creuzer, nor afraid to peep now and then even into Bryant, will not only find there a great useless mass of theories now deservedly repudiated, but will also find a great store of curious learning and will be guided to many obscure sources of useful knowledge.
